His Excellency Alfred Moloney, C.M.G., Governor of the British colony of Lagos, was amongst the Cameroon’s passengers.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-05-06', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/06_05_1889#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.632, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'As the time approaches we see on all sides steps being inaugurated to insure a fitting celebration of the Queen's Jubilee. In all parts of the Mother Country, throughout the length and breadth of the great Indian Empire, with its teeming millions of diverse races and languages, in the vast North-west Dominion, in the great Island-continent of the South, in the many Colonies in Asia, Africa, and the Isles, the thoughts of all who own the name of Briton are turned in loyal devotion to her who, through fifty years, "in that fierce light which beats about the throne," has performed the duties of her high office in such a way as to win the admiration and respect of all nations. The Jubilee of Queen Victoria is an occasion such as seldom happens in the history of nations. Apart from the rarity of a Sovereign's reign being extended to half a century, and beyond, it would be almost, if not quite, impossible to recall any similar period in the history of this or any other nation, whether of ancient or modern times, which has witnessed so vast an improvement in the social condition of the people, or so great an advance of the influence and extent of the Empire. When William IV. died (June 20, 1837), the Indian Empire was really but a geographical expression; Canada was of little account, either as a field of enterprise for our surplus population, or an appanage of the Crown; Australia was not opened up to commercial enterprise; and the British possessions in Africa consisted of little, if any, more than Cape Colony on the South and Sierra Leone on the West Coast. This latter settlement, indeed, had just reached the fiftieth year of its own existence in 1837, so that in 1887 it is called upon to celebrate its own Centenary along with the Jubilee of its Queen. There are many schemes before the public for insuring fitting memorials of the great occasion, but the one which appeals most directly to the amour propre of all Britons, and which indeed has the direct sanction of the popular Heir to the Throne, is the Imperial Institute, which is designed to serve at the same time as a memorial of the Jubilee and an institution which may afford a thorough representation of the progress achieved in the development of the resources of the Empire—a fitting national memorial of an epoch within.', 'last_edit_date': '1887-05-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_05_1887#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.644, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'On Sunday, June 20th, Her Majesty the Queen entered the fiftieth year of her reign. A reign so long and so eventful cannot but profoundly impress the imagination of all her subjects and those even outside her own dominions. In the old Jewish Commonwealth the occurrence of the jubilee—not, let it be remarked in passing, the fulfilment of the half-century, but the completion of seven times seven years—was an event of great solemnity and rejoicing; and the jubilee of the reign of the gracious lady whose influence for good has been so marked, far and wide, is an occasion in which all the 305,000,000 souls and more who comprise the vast British Empire have good cause to rejoice. The imagination recoils from the attempt to depict the vast changes—material, moral, and political—which have taken place since the 20th of June, 1837, when, early in the morning, the Princess Victoria was awakened from sleep to meet the Ministers who insisted upon seeing "THE QUEEN." At that time railway travelling was a novelty, steam navigation was in its infancy, and the electric telegraph—now in the jubilee year extended to West Africa—had not yet emerged from the laboratory. In this enumeration is comprised a revolution hardly less momentous than that effected by the invention of gunpowder and printing, or the ecclesiastical Reformation of the sixteenth century. In political affairs the changes which the Queen has witnessed are equally vast. Canada was, fifty years ago, a small and discontented, now it is a vast and contented dominion, with territories which will one day make it a rival not unworthy of the great Republic on its borders. Australasia has been called into being, and its youth is as that of a giant. India has been pacified and subdued, though not without great cost and sacrifices. We have had reverses; but in the wars waged in the reign of Queen Victoria the British soldiers have all along fought with the heroism and endurance which their fathers showed before.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1886#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.657, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'them, and have proved that the old martial fibre is as tough as ever in their nature. There have been English Sovereigns—and English Queens even—who have led a more public life; but there never was a Sovereign whose private life was lived more in the sight of her subjects, and who took them more completely into her confidence, or was more ready to seek their sympathy and to invite them to share her happiness. Englishmen have seen the Queen, a young woman alone among the councillors of her realm, bearing herself with dignity, self-possession, and grace. They have seen her on State occasions, such as her own Coronation or the opening of the great Colonial Exhibition, worthily representing the best traditions of the British Crown; and they have followed with a deep personal interest the story of her married life, and have sympathized with her in the irreparable calamity she sustained in the loss of her husband—a sorrow, though old in years, ever fresh in her mind. Queen Victoria has occupied the throne with dignity and wisdom, both in youth and age, and she has won the hearts of her subjects because, while never forgetting that she is a Queen, she has allowed them to see that she is also a true-hearted woman. It is the prayer of all her people that her influence and example may long be spared to them.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1886#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.693, 'probability_score': 0.07, 'summary': []}]

hh: The proposed repatriation of African descendants from the British West Indies to British Central Africa seeks to reconnect them with their ancestral homeland and promote economic and cultural development.
result: The General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles provide complementary insights into the proposed repatriation of African descendants from the British West Indies to British Central Africa, though they differ in geographical focus and historical context. The General History of Africa discusses various back-to-Africa movements and emigration schemes from the late 19th and early 20th centuries, highlighting figures like Marcus Garvey and organizations such as the American Colonization Society, which aimed to facilitate the return of African descendants to Africa for economic and cultural development. However, it primarily focuses on emigration to West Africa, particularly Liberia, and regions like South Africa and the Gold Coast, without specifically addressing the British West Indies to British Central Africa route. In contrast, The African Times articles directly align with the claim by detailing a scheme to acquire land in British Central Africa for settling descendants from the British West Indies, emphasizing the development of resources and civilization among natives. These articles underscore the economic and cultural aspects of the claim, highlighting land allocation, financial support, and the cultural reconnection to the "land of their fathers." They also introduce the broader context of European involvement and the necessity of European supervision, suggesting complexities and external influences not explicitly mentioned in the claim. Together, these sources provide a nuanced understanding of the historical efforts to reconnect African descendants with their ancestral homelands, while also highlighting differences in geographical focus and the perceived agency of the repatriated individuals.

[{'document_title': 'Africa and the New World', 'section_title': 'Conclusions', 'content': 'In broad pan-Africanist terms, however, the evidence seems clear that African political and ideological visions were expanded and technical expertise was improved because of colonial African interactions with American blacks. The much-heralded black emigration schemes trumpeted by Garvey, whose ubiquitous publications reached deep into Africa, were only one example of a leitmotif which brought American blacks within the world view of African peoples. The themes of African redemption through American black missionaries were another.
Africans themselves, however, created the context of their next interaction with American blacks as they matriculated at American, largely Afro-American, schools and attended pan-African conferences and the like. Consequently, many Africans underwent a technical-educationalpolitical experience alien to their colonial world. When they re-entered their own worlds, many felt driven to resolve questions of ideology, cultural definition, educational values, political power, and pan-African unity or consciousness, guided by new perspectives.
Viewed against such an historical backdrop, the numerous pan-African conferences, Tuskegean educational and technical projects, the nØgritude movement and the occasional focus on American blacks in African millen› nial dreams, all illustrate the consistency of the pan-African theme among American and Caribbean blacks. They also show the variability of African responses to the New World overtures and ultimately the shaping by Africans themselves of these overtures to fit African specifications.
In sum, the populations of the African diaspora and the motive charac› terizing the many interactions between persons of the first and second black worlds included two visions. One was a vision of the union of religious forces among black populations in Africa and America or the reconstruction of Africa through importation of American and Antillean black technical expertise, initiated at the behest of American blacks. Another reflected the transformation of Africans from predicate to subject during the colonial period. The latter was a vision of the spiritual redemption, social recon› struction, and political reformation of African communities through the repatriation of African personnel and the energizing of African resources. Because of this vision, Africans had been educated in American schools, or sent to participate in technical and commercial activities; others were touched by American black writings or by anti-colonial ventures organized among blacks of the diaspora. This latter vision seemed not so much to discard as simply to vindicate and to reorientate to an African perspective the idealism implied in the earlier vision.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Africa and the New World', 'section_title': 'Back-to-Africa movements', 'content': "Because of his general appeal to black pride, Garvey focused the attention of millions of American blacks on Africa in the period following the First World War. [{'id': 282, 'article_title': 'Coloured American Emigration to Africa', 'full_section_title': 'Coloured American Emigration to Africa', 'last_edit_date': '12-23-1863', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1863#article-19', 'issue_date': '23_12_1863', 'content': 'A correspondent of long experience in Africa, and who has lately been all along the Coast, from Senegal to the confines of the Portuguese territories south of the Line, writes:—

"I am more than ever confirmed in my opinion, that it would be one of the greatest boons we could confer on these benighted countries, to return to their fatherland those who have been Christianised in the land of their bondage—men who have
[DECEMBER 23, 1863.]

learned different trades, and especially cultivation, and who would go into cotton and sugar cultivation, and who would volunteer to come out relying solely on their own industry. If directed to proper localities, the results would be as beneficial to them as to this country. You are slowly, but surely, paving the way for an immigration of this kind into Africa."

Yes. We are preparing, by the measures and the changes we propose, and promote, an Africa for the reception of such men, while the war in America seems to be slowly, but surely, preparing the coloured race for that increase of self-reliance which they have needed to acquire previous to emigration.'}, {'id': 5969, 'article_title': 'THE AFRICAN PROBLEM', 'full_section_title': 'THE AFRICAN PROBLEM', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-7', 'issue_date': '01_04_1890', 'content': "Colonisationists have always recognised the manhood of the Negro and been willing to trust him to take care of himself. They have recognised the inscrutable providence by which the African was brought to these shores. They have taught that he was brought hither to be trained to a knowledge of his place as a factor in the great work of humanity; and that he could find his proper sphere of action only in the land of his origin. They have believed that it has not been given to the white man to fix the intellectual or spiritual status of this race. They have recognised that the universe is wide enough to allow the man of Africa to find out a path of his own within the circle of human interests, and to contribute from the field of his enterprise to the resources of the great human family. But will the Negro go to do this work? Is he willing to separate himself from a settled civilisation which he has helped to build up to betake himself to the wilderness of his ancestral home and begin anew a career on his own responsibility? I believe that he is.

The work to be done beyond the seas is not to be a reproduction of what we see in this country. It requires distinct race perception and entire race devotion. It is not to be the healing up of an old sore, but the unfolding of a new bud, an evolution; the development of a new side of God's character, and a new phase of humanity.

You can easily see why one race overshadowed by another should long to express itself—should yearn for the opportunity to let out the divinity that stirs within it. This is why the Hebrews cried to God from the depths of their affliction in Egypt, and this is why thousands of Negroes in the South are longing to go to the land of their fathers. They are not content to remain where everything has been done on the line of another race. They long for the scenes where everything is to be done under the influence of a new racial spirit, under the impulse of new skies and the inspiration of a fresh development. Only those are fit for this new work who believe, in the race—a prophetic insight into its destiny from a consciousness of its possibilities. The inspiration of the race is in the race.

Only one race has furnished the prophets for humanity—the Hebrew race; and before they were qualified to do this they had to go down to the depths of servile degradation. Only to them were revealed those broad principles upon which every race can stand and work and grow; but for the special work of each race the prophets arise among the people themselves."}, {'id': 6764, 'article_title': 'Elephants and the Ivory Trade', 'full_section_title': 'Elephants and the Ivory Trade', 'last_edit_date': '10-01-1896', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_10_1896', 'content': '"AFRICA FOR AFRICANS."

TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

SIR,—Allow me to excite the interest of your readers in a scheme which I am at present promoting, on behalf of the African race, of which I am a member.

The project, briefly stated, is to acquire a tract of land in British Central Africa, and to utilise the descendants of the race now resident in the British West Indies for the purpose of developing its resources, and for the furtherance of civilisation among the Natives. A grant of 10,000 acres, situated near a civilised centre, is required as a basis. The land will be divided into ten sections of 1,000 acres each; and, upon each of these divisions, ten carefully selected and well-trained families will be located. A sum of £25,000 will be required to enable the settlers to hold out for the first three years, while adjusting themselves to their new habitat, and to pay for the land should it be found necessary to purchase it.

During this period each head of a family would receive sufficient food and clothing for himself and his household, but would not be entitled to any further remuneration. At the beginning of the fourth year, however, an additional allowance of £30 per annum would, in like manner, be given, as it is hoped that by that time an income would be obtained from the land under cultivation. This arrangement would continue until the close of the tenth year, when the land would become the property of the people. The net proceeds of their earnings during this said period would be employed in the spread of civilisation among the Natives, and in the assisting of other enterprising Africans who were desirous of returning and settling down in their Fatherland.

The £25,000 necessary to float the scheme is not required at present. It will be raised with the help of a Committee'}, {'id': 6766, 'article_title': 'AFRICA FOR AFRICANS', 'full_section_title': 'AFRICA FOR AFRICANS', 'last_edit_date': '10-01-1896', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1896#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_10_1896', 'content': 'TO THE EDITOR OF THE AFRICAN TIMES.

SIR,—Allow me to excite the interest of your readers in a scheme which I am at present promoting, on behalf of the African race, of which I am a member.

The project, briefly stated, is to acquire a tract of land in British Central Africa, and to utilise the descendants of the race now resident in the British West Indies for the purpose of developing its resources, and for the furtherance of civilisation among the Natives. A grant of 10,000 acres, situated near a civilised centre, is required as a basis. The land will be divided into ten sections of 1,000 acres each; and, upon each of these divisions, ten carefully selected and well-trained families will be located. A sum of £25,000 will be required to enable the settlers to hold out for the first three years, while adjusting themselves to their new habitat, and to pay for the land should it be found necessary to purchase it.

During this period each head of a family would receive sufficient food and clothing for himself and his household, but would not be entitled to any further remuneration. At the beginning of the fourth year, however, an additional allowance of £30 per annum would, in like manner, be given, as it is hoped that by that time an income would be obtained from the land under cultivation. This arrangement would continue until the close of the tenth year, when the land would become the property of the people. The net proceeds of their earnings during this said period would be employed in the spread of civilisation among the Natives, and in the assisting of other enterprising Africans who were desirous of returning and settling down in their Fatherland.

The £25,000 necessary to float the scheme is not required at present. It will be raised with the help of a Committee

when the proper time arrives. I purpose, first of all, to go, spy out, and secure the land; secondly, to proceed to the West Indies to select the first 100 families as pioneers.

To meet this preliminary expense and charges already incurred in connexion with the maturing and developing of the scheme, a sum of not less than £650 is required. About £300 of this moderate amount has already been subscribed by more than 200 highly representative friends, and further contributions are earnestly solicited from all who take an interest in the progress of the African race.

Subscriptions can be sent to the Treasurers—Edward P. Thomson, Esq., W.S., 76 George Street, Edinburgh; and Alexander Breingan, Esq., Bank of Scotland, Helensburgh, N.B.—who will duly acknowledge the same. The name and address of each subscriber, together with the amount given, will then be entered in one of the official books, specially provided for the purpose. As soon as the necessary sum is obtained, a printed list of all the subscriptions will be published, along with a statement of the expenditure, and a copy sent to each subscriber.'}]

[{'document_title': 'Repatriation of West African Natives', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The energetic Governor of Lagos is interesting himself in a movement the results of which may be of doubtful benefit to West Africa. In August last he received at Lagos a representative deputation "of the Brazilian and Havannah repatriates in the colony of Lagos." It is not stated whether these representatives are pure negroes or mulattoes; but judging from their names—Senhor Ferreia, Senhor Agost Mendez, Senhor P. F. Da Costa—they seem to be a stage above the ordinary Brazilian negro. Moreover, the conclusion one naturally comes to from the tenour of the report of the meeting is that these representatives are Brazilian born and not emigrants from West Africa; therefore, it seems remarkable that they should be able to speak the language of the people of Yoruba, the country which lies inland from Lagos, and that the traditions and language of West Africa should be still kept up among the negroes on the other side of the Atlantic. In reply to the inquiry of the Governor these representatives assured him that all the negroes of Brazil wished to return to their country, although they admitted that the older men were much more anxious to return than the Creoles. At the same time they stated that the majority were anxious to "repatriate" themselves. The Governor immediately concluded that half the negro population of Brazil (1,000,000) were eager to leave the land where many of them had been slaves, and return to a country where, no doubt, they believe they will be absolutely independent. Poverty, the representatives stated, was the only thing that prevented them from carrying out their wishes. The Governor then informed the deputation that he had succeeded in inducing the commercial world to take an interest in this movement. The African Steamship Company have agreed to run their vessel, the Biafra, between Lagos and Brazil, purely, however, as a commercial speculation. The fares for negroes passing to and from Brazil will be as low as possible, while the deck accommodation will be comfortable. But the migration is not to be all on one side. The Governor of Lagos is convinced that negro labour is absolutely necessary to the development of the resources of Brazil, and now that a republic has been established, such labour will be more and more in demand. Moreover, there is already a fair trade between West Africa and Brazil, which is no doubt capable of considerable extension. Sir Alfred Moloney's idea, therefore, is not only to encourage the "repatriation" of Brazilian negroes but to establish a system of contract labour, by means of which the West African native may go to Brazil for a series of years, and return home with his savings, with habits of industry, and possibly with the knowledge of some handicraft. The Governor is persuaded that this would be good for his colony. At present these West African colonies are dependent upon one commodity, oil, and they have suffered much from recent depreciation in its price. Governor Moloney has done much to induce the natives to attend to other products, natural and introduced. If, therefore, the repatriation of Brazilian negroes will stimulate the stay-at-home native to the industrial development of their country, much good will be done. But that is the question. From the history of Liberia it seems doubtful whether the native will be able to do more than scrape together a bare living. Moreover, it seems very likely that 1,000,000 Brazilian negroes and half-castes are awaiting "repatriation" in a country where they would not be half as well off as they are at present. Still, Sir Alfred Moloney's experiment is worth making, and everyone will wish that the result may be for the good of the "repatriates," the natives, and the colony generally. It may be remembered that a somewhat similar movement is on foot in the United States; and no doubt if half the present negro population of North America could be deported to Liberia, the Congo, and elsewhere in Africa, it would be a great relief to their present country.—*Times.*', 'last_edit_date': '1890-11-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/07_11_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.704, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "The example and supervision of great numbers of educated Europeans will be necessary. No African will feel disposed to dispute this statement who recognises the immense advantages which Europe possesses through the gradual accumulation of inherited wealth and science during many centuries of progress and the comparative infancy of civilisation in Western Africa; nor will he object to the creation, by European skill and experience, of commerce and agriculture, which, while amply repaying the capital expended, will gradually create tenfold wealth for the benefit of the negro races. It may, perhaps, be reasonably held that the advance of civilisation will be more rapid than Sir George Goldie ventures to anticipate, and that some now living may see prosperous negro communities developing the rich soil of Central Africa, with their lives unshadowed by the horrors of bloodshed, slavery, and cruel superstition. It will be interesting in connexion with this subject to watch the outcome of Sir Alfred Moloney's proposal for the repatriation into his colony of Lagos of negroes from Brazil, as the success of this scheme would be a strong encouragement to the larger proposals to which Dr. Blyden has for many years devoted his talents—namely, the repatriation of the negroes from the United States. It is admitted by the Niger Company that they already have to depend largely in their territory on the services of their coloured officials, natives of the British Colonies, who have proved invaluable for treaty-making and diplomatic intercourse with the native chiefs, as well as for the development of new products in which the Company has apparently made rapid progress.

Sir George Goldie does not refer, however, in his article to two of the most important features in the policy of the Company. By the first, they have secured tens of millions of the African race from the spread of the liquor traffic. Lord Aberdare's speech last July should be hung in large type in every room of the Colonial Office. He said:—", 'last_edit_date': '1891-02-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_02_1891#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.669, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Present Outlook on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The people who would have been transferred would probably, for the most part, have known nothing of their change of nationality, and there can be little doubt that the material prosperity of the colony would have been increased by its being joined to Senegal and receiving attention similar to that which has been lavished on the neighbouring French possessions, whilst in the Gaboon we should have received what even then would have been a valuable equivalent. — *Manchester Guardian.*', 'last_edit_date': '1885-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1885#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE FUTURE OF THE BRITISH WEST AFRICAN SETTLEMENTS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Such being the feeling in Great Britain with regard to our colonies generally, Africa is not likely to be made an exception. The colonization of the West Coast by Europeans is not a very probable event. The colonies formed there must consequently be colonies of the African race, and for the most part natives of the lands constituting or bordering on those of the colony. To raise these natives from the debased and degraded state into which they have fallen, both morally and physically—to free them from the bloody and demoralizing influence of beastly superstitions, from polygamy, from domestic slavery, from the paralyz-', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-22', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/22_07_1865#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'In all the coast region between the Gambia and the Cameroons the most extravagant development of tropical vegetation is seen. The great future wealth of the interior plateaux will certainly lie in their mineral deposits, the riches of the West Coast region lie in its numerous and valuable vegetable products, of which the most striking are palm oil, and ground nuts, benniseed, shea butter, rubber, gums, spices, cotton, dyes, and valuable timbers, among which ebony occupies a prominent place. With regard to animal products, I might mention ivory and monkey skins. Whereas some of the great races of the interior speak languages which connect them with the Hamitic and Semitic families. The native inhabitants of the West Coast are all that there is of most typically Negro in character; yet I do not mean they are races of particularly low development; on the contrary, the typical Negro is a fine specimen of man, and is by no means as low in his mental state as the races of Polynesia and America. I may cite the Kru tribes of that portion of West Africa which is known as Liberia, a country inhabited by an industrious, energetic, hardworking, stalwart population of free men. An element of heterogeneous ex-slave settlers among the tribes of the coast may be found in some parts of the Colonies of Sierra Leone, Gambia, Gold Coast, and Lagos. These people represent the Nemesis which invariably follows national crimes. We and our American children indulged to a greater extent than any other European nation in the African slave trade, and, as our wrong-doing was violent and exaggerated, so to a certain extent was the abrupt reparation which followed. Although I would not minimise the work done by our blockade on the West Coast, the abolition of the slave trade was more effectually brought about by the abolition of slavery in the United States of America. One result of our suppression of the slave trade in West Africa has not been altogether advantageous. I refer to the Slave Colonies established at Sierra Leone, and at Fernando Po and other points on the coast. It may be taken that the slaves exported from any district are the least worthy people in it, and the result is that a large proportion of this population is descended from the sweepings of West Africa, and has not yet passed through sufficient generations to eliminate the ancestral badness of its progenitors. So, although here and there a negro has shown what the race can attain to under favourable circumstances, still the bulk of the "S'a Leone" people who are scattered up and down the coast are of an undesirable character, and the cause of indiscriminating blame on the part of superficial observers which is most unjustly laid on the shoulders of the entire population of West Africa; whereas many of these races are superior in intelligence, enterprise, and integrity to any of our negro fellow-subjects in South Africa or the West Indies. What admirable recruits to civilised society can be obtained from many of these people may be instanced by such men as Bishop Crowther, Archdeacons Johnson and Crowther, Samuel Lewis, and other divines and lawyers and officials in West Africa, who are on a par with well-educated white men, and in some cases superior in intelligence and acquirements to the whites with whom they come in contact. It is absurd, however, to regard the Negro race, as a whole, on the same average level as the European—they are far below us. Take them in their native wilds, and they are what we were before Julius Caesar landed in this country; indeed, in many cases they are not 2,000 years behind us, but 10,000. They are in the condition of some of the earliest inhabitants of Britain, and Gaul, and Spain, whose history we can dimly spell out from their implements and scattered remains, who were undoubtedly cannibals and probably naked, and leading a brutish life. Yet we can in a few years drag them from the condition that prevailed 2,000 years before Christ into the year of grace 1889. We can take a cannibal from the Upper Cross River, and transport him to the centres of civilisation in England or America, where everything represents the utmost result of our present development; but what will be usually the result both with the individual and the race? The savage mind will be unable to grasp and assimilate one-third of the wonders presented to his consideration, and will probably even suffer from the shock. We cannot expect the negroes of West Africa to become all at once intelligent, self-governing people. For many years the white races must be their guardians and educators, and we must educate the negro by force if necessary, leaving him to understand us afterwards, when we have raised him to a condition to do so. This, then, is our mission in West Africa: to instruct the natives that idleness is the eighth deadly sin; next, to so instruct the native as to the existence of the resources of this country; and, lastly, to educate him in the principles of civilised society, and so assimilate his views with our own that he and we may be bound together with the ties of commerce and Empire.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.676, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'A CALL TO ACTION IN CENTRAL AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The value of Lancashire mill property has decreased one-half during the last three years. And the possessors of wealth must not suppose that the effect of such a decrease is merely local. It has already affected, and will affect, the whole country; and it is not too much to affirm that every possessor of property throughout the kingdom would act wisely in devoting a percentage of it to the forwarding of enterprises which, like that so luminously urged by Mr. Bradshaw, have aforetime brought new wealth and power into the land. There never was an axiom more true than that property has its duties as well as its rights. Let them reflect for a moment what their position will be a few years hence, when the population has risen, say, to forty millions, if no successful enterprise shall have opened extensive new marts for our manufactures, and developed the now dormant and unutilized resources of old ones. For this one thing is certain—the people will be fed. No argument will suffice to prove to millions of empty or only half-filled stomachs, that "sacredness of property," the belief in which can alone save property from destruction. The sooner this truth sinks into the minds of the possessors of property, and so influences their conduct as to urge them to exertion in the direction now pointed out, the better for them and for the country at large. The lately explored regions of Africa offer scope for an enterprise as glorious and as fruitful in wealth-giving results as that of the old East India Company, to which Great Britain is indebted for that richest of all her over-sea possessions. What has to be done must be done on a grand scale. Africa will never be civilized, to say nothing about its being Christianized, and its enormous resources developed and utilized, by dribblets of enterprise, which for the most part enfold within themselves the germs of inevitable failure. A great work can be only greatly performed. The industrial redemption of Africa, the bringing its large interior population into beneficial and permanent relation with European civilization, is a work worthy of the highest ambition to undertake and to accomplish. It is the duty, as well as for the interest, of the people of Great Britain to undertake it; and they will ere long bitterly repent if they persistently neglect a duty so imperative, so pressing, and so sacred.', 'last_edit_date': '1879-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1879#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.665, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'What the Royal Niger Company is Doing for West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'It should be borne in mind by those who look for quick and fabulous returns from their investments that Africa occupies a singular position. After countless generations have despised Africa, there seems now to be a disposition to go to the other extreme and imagine that untold wealth is about to flow from the interior of this continent. The fact is that generations must pass before the country can be properly developed. We are not dealing with a country in which there are accumulated wealth, acquired habits of industry, and a knowledge of art, but with peoples who are absolutely ignorant. There is potential wealth in the land, but it must be cultivated. At present no trade is done except in forest products. By-and-by, when they are taught, they will begin to cultivate the soil and raise products which are in demand in Europe. Indigo will be one of these, and Africa will become one of the great indigo-producing countries of the world. The chartered companies meanwhile will, no doubt, do fairly well, not making great returns, but sufficient to repay their shareholders for their investment, while developing and creating a great country and a large market for our manufactures. As to the demand for

our goods, that is a question that need not trouble us. The natives are fully alive to the advantage of British manufactures, and they will take any amount. The demand is only limited by what they can give in return, and the offer of British goods is the inducement which the companies hold out to them to produce the wealth of their own country.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1888#article-0', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Development of Tropical Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Some portions being densely and some only sparsely populated, and there were portions of the Congo basin more densely populated than India. Where the population was only sparse, that might be accounted for by the tribal warfare which prevailed, and which could be suppressed by the introduction of civilisation. What was wanted was that peace should be maintained, and trade encouraged, to raise the natives to a civilised condition. The native population was divisible into three great classes—the Arab, the Negroid, and the Negro. The Arab race they met from the Nile to the Zambesi, and in the Sahara, as well as about the Great Lakes. They were the merchants and the traders, while the Negroids were the occupiers and cultivators of the soil. It was singular that, while the Arab race had endeavoured to oust the British from the Soudan, they had assisted them at Zanzibar. It was difficult to deal with them, and it would not do to drive them out as the Moors had been driven from Spain. The best thing to do would be to make them useful in Central Africa, to deal with them as we found them, and to place in their way such commercial prospects that they might be induced to abandon the slave trade. If they once got the Arab to join them, they could easily put a stop to the butcheries of the negro races by each other. As to the Negroids, they were being gradually absorbed by the other two races. The most important race to the British Empire was the Negro, who was capable of being rapidly civilised. He could not raise himself unaided, and he still remained as he had been limned 4,000 years ago upon the Egyptian frescoes. Yet as soon as he was brought into contact with civilisation he took it up rapidly, and soon became a good clerk, an engineer, a cook, or domestic servant. The Negro was far less alien to our civilisation than the Chinaman, and in the course of about 300 years there would be very little difference between him and the European except the colour of the skin. They might be weaned from slave-dealing, man-hunting, the burning of witches, and the offering of human sacrifices, and he did not know of any African prince who could be accused of anything like the beheadings and the quarterings that took place in the reigns of Henry VIII., Mary, and Elizabeth, nor did he find that any native African priesthood had been guilty of one-tenth of the horrible cruelty which had been perpetrated in Europe under the name of religion. In conclusion, he observed that if these portions of Africa with which he has been dealing could but be brought under the influence indicated, it would bring them an increase of knowledge, of wealth, and of power such as had accrued to them from their dominions in Asia.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-11-07', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/07_11_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH WEST AFRICA AND THE TRADE OF THE INTERIOR.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'If we have not parted with the energy and resolution which, as a Government and people, have characterised us of old, if we shall frame and carry out a sensible, settled policy in these regions, yielding to no sentimental clamour from false philanthropists, nor ignoring the just rights of the natives and our responsibility towards them as their guardians and instructors, we shall make of Western Africa another India, equally worthy of renown and equally profitable to our trade.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-02-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_02_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Proposed French and English Exchange of West African Settlements', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Irrespective of Imperial considerations and views, and of the questions of West African development and civilization involved in the matter of the proposed exchange of British and French settlements in West Africa, there must necessarily be particular and personal interests that would be affected by such changes of rule and system as are involved in the proposed measure, should it be carried into effect. These particular and personal interests have grown up under British rule in the Gambia, and are the only ones on the West Coast of any importance that would be jeopardized or interfered with by the contemplated transfers. The British free trade policy, which has opened the ports of all our settlements and colonies to foreign commerce, differs so essentially from the French protective system, under which, as at the Senegal, for instance, all possible British competition is prohibited, that the British merchants having establishments on the River Gambia—establishments, some of which were founded more than half a century ago—are very naturally apprehensive that in coming under the restrictive French colonial system, instead of the liberal British one, their interests will be seriously jeopardized; or, in brief, that they would very soon be driven out altogether from the Gambia as a French colony or settlement. We cannot say that these apprehensions are unfounded, and we have therefore not been at all surprised to find that the British merchants having establishments on the Gambia have been holding private meetings in London, during the past month, for mutual counsel and agreement as to the best course for them to pursue for their own protection in this emergency. We sympathize with them, and do not hesitate to say that it would be unjust on the part of Her Majesty’s Government to make the proposed exchange without some stipulation that shall protect their absolute interest. As we are strangers to their counsels, we have not heard what is their estimate of these interests, or what special course of action they may have decided to adopt in defence of them. We have, however, a very decided opinion of our own in the matter, and that opinion we shall unreservedly express. First, then, we think they will be very unwise if they adopt the course of opposition to the Imperial policy in this matter, either on Imperial grounds or on the grounds of any supposed rights that the Native populations in the Gambia may have to a continuance of British rule in their countries. These are questions with which as British merchants they have not any concern. Like all other British subjects, they may express fully and freely their opinions respecting them, but they will not be wise if they do more. Their opposition to the Imperial policy would necessarily have little or no weight, because it could not be separated from, but would infallibly be regarded as influenced by, personal considerations. We helped them in 1869-70 to fight the battle against the transfer of the Gambia to the French, on Imperial grounds, because the transfer, as then proposed, was motived by considerations unworthy of such an empire as that of Great Britain, and certain to bring upon her an enduring disgrace. The motives of Government action are, however, at the present time essentially different. It is no longer a question whether ten or twenty thousand pounds a-year can be saved to the Imperial exchequer by getting rid of the Gambia. That economy was made without getting rid of it. We cannot, therefore, as we stated last month, fight the battle over again on such grounds, because they no longer exist. The considerations that influence us ought also to influence the Gambia merchants on this point. We insist the more on this because we have heard that merchants not connected with the Gambia trade have been active in tendering their co-operation and support to the Gambia merchants in opposing the Government on these Imperial grounds. They have real or fancied interests of their own involved, no doubt, in the projected exchange of settlements; but their interests are not in any respect the interests of the Gambia merchants, who will do wisely to leave them to pull their own chestnuts out of the fire, if they have any that seem likely to be burned there; and decline the proffered aid which, if accepted, will weaken instead of strengthen their position. Their true policy seems to us very clear. It is that they should not oppose the Government views, which are supposed to be now based on Imperial considerations of sufficient weight to justify the Government in entertaining them. Their acquiescence or non-acquiescence will not eventually influence the Government decision. What they have a just right to ask, and should energetically and persistently ask, is that they should not be sacrificed to those Imperial considerations which may justify Her Majesty’s Government in exchanging the Gambia for the relinquishment by the French in favour of Great Britain of their settlements and interests on all other parts of the West Coast of Africa. The Gambia merchants have invested large sums in buildings and other immovable property, in the belief, which they were in every respect justified in entertaining, that the British settlement on the Gambia was a permanent one. The giving up by Great Britain of any settlement it has once formed is an event so extremely rare that there could not be any possible reason why the future cession of the Gambia to some other Power should have been at all contemplated or considered by them. There is not anything therefore in their position at the Gambia to diminish the force and justice of their claim, that in any arrangements made by the British Government with that of the French for the cession of the Gambia to the latter, their interests should be scrupulously guarded and preserved to the fullest extent of their pecuniary value. We have no doubt it is tolerably correct that it would be impossible for them to live and continue their trade at the Gambia as hitherto, when French authorities and laws shall have superseded those under whom and which they have hitherto lived and carried on their commerce. The cession of the Gambia to the French involves therefore their eventual ejection from the settlement. If they remain there striving against the new and adverse circumstances after the cession, and those circumstances act so prejudicially to their interests as they seem to us to be fully justified in believing that they will act, they might be forced into parting with their properties to French merchants at almost any price that the latter might choose to give. They are justified therefore in demanding of Her Majesty’s Government that they shall not be subject to any such contingency, but be so placed under the new rule and laws that, should the prejudicial results which they fear really follow, they may be able at any time to leave the Gambia and receive the full present value of their properties. It is not necessary for us to point out to such practical men as they are how this might be arranged for without any actual loss or burthen to the French Government. It might certainly be so arranged that should the change result adversely to them they shall receive the full present value of their properties; while at the same time they should be left free to realize as much more for these as they might be enabled to obtain. But, if the British policy there is to be such as has been shadowed forth in questions and answers in the committee-room, we are inclined to withdraw our opposition—nay more, to recommend what we most ardently opposed. The testimony to the entire discontinuance of the slave-trade, under any name or pretext, by France, has been general and convincing. If, therefore, because of economical considerations—because of the poverty of its exchequer, Great Britain declines to exercise such jurisdiction over the river and the natives along its banks, from the sea to M'Carthy's Island, as will as effectually repress violence, robbery, and war, stimulate production and commerce, and aid voluntary efforts for the dissemination of Christianity, we see no justification in her retaining the Gambia, provided the French Government will consent to acquire it on reasonable terms, and under such stipulations for entire freedom of trade, and protection to Christian missions, as we feel convinced the enlightened Emperor of the French would willingly agree to. Vol. I., p. 255.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1865#article-23', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist's point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? hh: The establishment of Christianity and treaties between British authorities and Egba chiefs fostered a cooperative relationship between Lagos and Abeokuta, essential for regional development and civilization.
result: The observations from the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles provide complementary insights into the claim that the establishment of Christianity and treaties between British authorities and Egba chiefs fostered a cooperative relationship between Lagos and Abeokuta, essential for regional development and civilization. The "General History of Africa" highlights the formation of the Egba United Board of Management at Abeokuta, which aimed to direct native government, forward civilization, and promote Christianity, indicating a cooperative effort between the educated elite and traditional rulers. This aligns with the claim of fostering regional development and civilization through the influence of British intervention and missionary activities, which contributed to socio-economic development. However, the textbook does not explicitly mention treaties between British authorities and Egba chiefs as a factor in the relationship between Lagos and Abeokuta. In contrast, The African Times articles provide specific details supporting the claim, highlighting the role of Christianity in promoting peace and civilization and describing successful treaties, such as the one concluded by Governor Carter, which established peace, friendship, and free trade between Lagos and the Egba country. These treaties marked a new era of cooperation and mutual benefit, with British authorities mediating disputes and fostering economic ties. The articles also emphasize the importance of improved communication and infrastructure, such as proposed railways, to further strengthen the relationship and promote development, while acknowledging challenges like lingering distrust. Together, these sources illustrate how Christianity and diplomatic agreements contributed to a cooperative dynamic between Lagos and Abeokuta, facilitating regional progress.

[{'document_title': 'African initiatives and resistance in West Africa, 1880-1914', 'section_title': 'Conquest and reaction in British West Africa, 1880-1900 > Southern Nigeria', 'content': 'Mainly as a result of the activities of the missionaries, British influence and trade had penetrated from Lagos, occupied in 1851, to most parts of Yorubaland, and a number of anti-slave trade, and trade and protection treaties had been concluded between the British and many Yoruba rulers by 1884. In 1886, the British administration was also able to convince Ibadan and the Ekitiparapo (comprising the Ekiti, Ijesha and Egba), who had been at war since 1879, to sign a peace treaty. That the British had accomplished so much in Yorubaland by 1886 should not surprise us. Apart from the activities of the European traders and missionaries, which had preceded the wars, after fighting among themselves since the 1850s, the Yoruba were themselves war-weary and needed peace; hence their acceptance of the intervention by the British. The only state in Yorubaland that had effectively resisted the missionaries, the British traders, and the Lagos administration, until the 1880s was Ijebu. Bent on occupying Yorubaland from the early 1890s, the British decided to teach Ijebu a lesson and at the same time demonstrate to the remaining Yoruba states the futility of opposing them.$^{46}$ Using an alleged insult to Governor Denton in 1892 as a pretext, the British launched a wellprepared expedition of about 1000 men armed with rifles, machine guns and a Maxim gun. The Ijebu courageously raised an army of between 7000 and 10000 men but in spite of this huge numerical superiority and in spite of the fact that some of them were armed with firearms, they were routed by the invaders.$^{47}$ It would appear that all the remaining Yoruba states learnt a lesson from this invasion, and it is not surprising that between 1893 and 1899 Abeokuta, Ibadan, Ekiti-Ijesa and Oyo readily agreed to negotiate treaties and accepted British residents. It was merely to ensure the total submission of the Alafin that the British bombarded Oyo in 1895. Abeokuta remained nominally independent until 1914.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.66, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'New trends and processes in Africa in the nineteenth century', 'section_title': 'New political trends', 'content': "The progressive and modern nature of the objectives of the Con› federation are truly astonishing while the spirit of harmonious co-operation between the educated elite and the traditional rulers pervading the Con› stitution was really revolutionary. Had this bold co-operative effort, which was very much inspired by the writings of Africanus Horton, been allowed to materialize and the plans implemented, the course not only of the history of the Gold Coast but probably the whole of British West Africa would have been different. But for reasons to be discussed later, the British had killed this bold and interesting initiative stone-dead by 1873. 59 A similar constitutional experiment was that of the Egba United Board of Management formed at Abeokuta. According to Africanus Horton, its express purpose was that 'of directing the native government, of forwarding civilization, and promoting the spread of Christianity, as well as of pro- tecting the property of European merchants and British subjects'.$^{60}$ A third example was the constitution for the kingdom of the Grebo, which, as Person points out, was set up in imitation of the Fante Confederation.
It should be evident from all this that in the political as in the religious and demographic fields, really fundamental changes were taking place and the roots of many of the basic issues of today - the relationship between the educated elite and the traditional rulers, the problems of socio-economic development, the idea of political independence, the concept and practice of pan-Africanism and the phenomenon of racial discrimination - can be found during the period under review.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Conclusion: Africa on the eve of the European conquest', 'section_title': 'Political structures', 'content': "Christianity served a similar purpose, providing a cultural framework for creating a Creole society out of disparate groups of peoples settled in Freetown and surrounding villages, as in various settlements on the Liberian coast, or in Libreville, Freretown, and other freed slave settlements. In various places, missionaries seeking converts often received a warm welcome from African rulers who, although very jealous of their inde- pendence and not keen to have their people converted, saw in missionary activities a possible access route to European education which might teach literacy and technical skills such as carpentry, printing and, if possible, also the manufacture of guns and gunpowder. The rulers of Madagascar tried to balance British Protestants and French Catholics, then rejected both and sought to ban their religious activities, and ended up getting the court and the bureaucratic elite to become Protestant while Catholicism made significant progress in some of the provinces. The rulers tried to use European ideas in diplomacy, judicial reforms, military reorganization and in establishing a constitutional monarchy.$^{13}$ Similarly, beleaguered as they were by aggressive white racialism, a number of the new states in Southern Africa such as Moshoeshoe's kingdom of the Basuto accepted missionaries as their advisers and external champions, protected them and even prom› ulgated laws to assist them in their work of conversion.$^{14}$ In the Fante states on the Gold Coast and at other important missionary centres, notably Abeokuta in south-western Yorubaland, a number of Western-educated African leaders used their literacy and European contacts to get reforms carried out in the traditional state structures. These included the creation of chancelleries to be managed by literate Africans to control diplomatic relations with Europeans and guide the external relations of the states; the reform of tax systems by the introduction of regulated taxes in place of tolls and tribute; and the improvement of the judicial system by the introduction of record-keeping and putting enacted laws into writing. 15", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.707, 'probability_score': 0.052, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Colonialism in Africa: its impact and significance', 'section_title': 'The colonial impact > The impact in the social field', 'content': 'The spread of Christianity, Islam and western education was another important impact of colonialism. There is no doubt that taking advantage of the peace and order as well as the patronage and in some areas the positive encouragement provided by colonialism, Christian missionaries and Muslim clerics pushed their activities further and further inland. As K. Asare Opoku has shown (Chapter 20), Christianity and Islam gained far more ground during the colonial period than had been the case during the previous three or four centuries put together. It was during this period that Christianity gained a firm foothold in East and Central Africa at times following or at times being followed by the flag and trade. Islam also spread rapidly in West and East Africa as a result of the general improvement of communications during the colonial period and the patronage of both the French and the British rulers. It should be emphasized, as Opoku has done, that these gains were not made at the expense of traditional religion. What colonialism did, then, was to strengthen and perpetuate religious pluralism in Africa and thereby enrich her religious life.
Closely associated with the spread of Christianity was that of western education. As has been shown in many of the chapters above, the Christian missions were mainly responsible for this. It should, however, be borne in mind that they could operate mainly because of the grants they received from the colonial administrations. Certainly, by the end of the colonial regime, there were relatively few areas without at least elementary schools. The spread of western education had far-reaching social effects among which was an increase in the number of the westernized educated African elite, an elite which now constitutes the ruling oligarchy and the backbone of the civil service of African states.
Another important colonial impact, a mixed blessing as will be shown later, was of course the provision of a lingua franca for each colony or set of colonies. In all the colonies, the mother tongue of the colonial power, either in its pure or pidgin form, became the official and business language and in many cases the main means of communication between the numerous linguistic groups that constitute the population of each colony. It is signifi› cant that except in North Africa, Tanzania, Kenya and Madagascar, these languages have remained the official languages even to this very day.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.662, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The eastern delta', 'content': 'In addition to the British consuls and naval officers on the coast, British traders and missionaries tried to get into the hinterland, for example, by sponsoring voyages of exploration. Many decades of British efforts to discover the course and sources of the Niger river were crowned with success when Richard and John Lander were brought from Aboh to Nembe (Brass) by its ruler, King Boy Amain, in 1830. Once the estuaries of the many rivers of the Niger delta were shown to be the entrance to the great Niger river, British interest was greatly increased in the area as a highway into the rich interior of Nigeria and West Africa. British traders, such as Macgregor Laird, as well as humanitarians and missionaries tried to move up the delta into the hinterland between the 1830s and 1850s.
In the eastern delta itself, the Church Missionary Society under the leadership of the Nigerian ex-slave, Bishop Samuel Ajayi Crowther, estab› lished missions at Bonny in 1864, at Twon-Brass in the Nembe kingdom in 1868, at Elem Kalahari (New Calabar in the documents) in 1874, and at Okrika in 1880. Both at Bonny and Nembe, the rulers invited the missionaries for a number of reasons. Some wished to have the missionaries establish schools in which their children could learn to read, write and speak English in order to carry on their commercial relations with British firms. It was also believed that permission for the missionaries would lead to better relations with the British government, represented by the consuls and naval officers, and serve to strengthen them against neighbouring states in internal power struggles. These same reasons sometimes led to the missionaries being rejected in other parts of the eastern delta. Thus, once the Church Missionary Society was established at Bonny, Jaja of Opobo, who had broken away from Bonny in 1869 to form his state of Opobo, would have nothing to do with that mission. The establishment of Christian missions was, however, resisted by powerful interests within each of the delta states, and Christianity constituted a factor of social instability in the nineteenth century. Dike considered that Christianity turned the slaves into revolutionaries who created upheavals in these states; but recent research has discovered other social and political factors to explain the problems of the delta states in the nineteenth century. 7', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.664, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'Introduction', 'content': 'Early relationships evidenced by linguistic similarities and attested by traditions of origin and migrations were reinforced by contact through trade in the nineteenth century.$^{2}$ Trade routes established before the nineteenth century traversed the Niger delta from east to west, and to the hinterland, to join other routes stretching to the north. European traders along the coast, and gradually up the rivers, made use of the long-established centres of trade on the coast, and received goods brought down from the hinterland. Accordingly, the European presence on the coast became another unifying factor in the history of the region, presenting common problems and stimuli to change. Thus, each of the communities in the region underwent changes or adaptations in their social, political or cultural structures in the face of the external influences and challenge of European intrusion. The factors of European activity included: (i) the slave trade and the effects of its abolition in the nineteenth century; (2) the change to trade in local produce in place of slaves, sometimes referred to as legitimate trade; (3) the entry of Christian missionaries into the region, and (4) the onset of European imperialism and colonial conquest. Although the treaty of 1833 between Nicolls and King William was rejected, British agents concluded treaties between 1840 and 1844 that provided them with the legal basis for intervention in local politics. In Lagos, on the edge of the Brazilian Quarter, a central mosque was erected by craftsmen from Brazil (Plate 29.5).
Furthermore, the Catholics$^{35}$ built their first church, the Holy Cross Church, started in 1879, in Lagos, and sent their children to the schools of the French and English missionaries who were beginning to use English and French for their teaching.

The continual growth of the population, and its eagerness to put down roots, made improvement of the amenities impera› tive. As the seat of the colonial government and the naval Vice-Admiralty, the victualling base for the naval patrol, and the official liberation centre for the Mixed Commissions, Freetown and the interior could count on a more or less regular injection of subsidies. MacCarthy improved the early villages and built new ones, where new arrivals were adopted and settled down among brothers. Vague European notions of model communities contrasted with African values, ways of life and traditional activities. Land and property in the town appreciated in value, and craft industries and trade opened the way to personal prosperity. Around 1828 enterprising individuals secured the entrØe to the coast's new type of economy. In 1831 the colony was opened to foreign trade. The British upper and ruling classes financed the churches and the smaller denominations, whose personnel had had no training whatsoever in anti-slavery or missionary work. Sierra Leone became their training ground. In addition to spreading Christianity and civilization the missions had to fight the slave trade, especially at Rio Pongos. But local slave-traders suspected these people of spying for the colonial government: they set fire to buildings of the Church Missionary Society who abandoned the field. In the colony itself, where political authority was conscious of its humanitarian mission, the missionaries were not unconscious of politics. In the civil administration, despite acute personal and doctrinal rivalries, the co-operation of powerful personalities with the government achieved sound long-term results. First, it led to an increased British presence in the Bight of Bonny. Ekechi, 'the most bewildering mass movement of the 1900s has been partly attributed to Igbo attempts to circumvent various forms of British overrule'; while Simon Ottenberg believes that the Igbo have been particularly receptive to change because of their social structures, attitudes, and history.$^{11}$ However, there is no evidence that the Igbo have, in fact, discarded their traditional culture and religion for Christianity to a much greater extent than other comparable groups in Nigeria and the rest of Africa.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.691, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'States and peoples of the Niger Bend and the Volta', 'section_title': 'Religious change', 'content': "In this region the nineteenth century was a period of rapid advance for Islam in the north and centre, while Christianity was reintroduced in the south. In the northern part of the region the wide influence of the djihâds led by eminent men ('Uthmän Dan Fodio of Sokoto, Seku Ahmadu of Massina and al-Hadjdj 'Umar Tal) produced powerful and lasting effects, as, for example, the djihad and the emirate of Liptako.
Even the Bambara and Mossi kingdoms were carried along in the wake of this uprush of Islamic proselytizing activity, or at any rate influenced by it. The Bambara and the Mossi have usually been termed 'ramparts against the expansion of Islam', but if this clichØ was ever true, it certainly was not so in the nineteenth century, when Islam was a powerful force not only at the top of the social order in these kingdoms, but in every part of society. Monzón Jara's successor asked a learned marabout who was a friend of his for a talisman that would bring him victory. Torokoro Mari (1854-6) turned over one of his sons to al-Hadjdj 'Umar and asked the latter to bring him up; to be sure, this induced the monarch's warriors to abandon their allegiance and drown him, explaining to his successor, 'We killed your brother because he wanted to compel us to become Muslims, and because he was squandering the state's resources by showering gifts on marabouts'. 65 In the Mossi kingdoms, the only Muslims up to that point had been the YarsØ, but early in the nineteenth century the Mogho-Naaba openly embraced the Islamic faith and in their turn these established nuclei of missionary activity.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.654, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Niger delta and the Cameroon region', 'section_title': 'The Niger delta > The western delta', 'content': 'In the nineteenth century, the western delta did not become as important as the eastern delta as a centre for the overseas trade in slaves, palm oil and palm kernels.
