The first British consul to the Bights of Benin and Bonny in 1849, John Beecroft, settled at Fernando Po, close to the Cameroon coast and the eastern Niger delta. It was only in 1891 that a vice-consul was sent to the inland port of Sapele in the western delta to monitor the penetration of the Nigerian hinterland in this area. By this time, the scramble for African territories had started, and Nana Olomu had to fight to try to stop them. The missionaries followed the flag in the western delta.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.655, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Religion in Africa during the colonial era', 'section_title': 'Islam and colonial rule', 'content': 'try to cope with Islam and established institutes to study and document Muslim life, beliefs, practices and institutions. 22 Colonial powers were determined to break up large Muslim states and religious organizations and to foster rivalry and competition among them. Thus the British abolished the Sokoto caliphate in Northern Nigeria while the French openly encouraged the ethnic and dynastic rivalries which led to the disintegration of the Tukulor empire (see Fig. 6.2) and the proliferation of Sufi orders, and refused to recognize one Khalifa for all Muslim members of the Tijaniyya order in West Africa.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.656, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The social repercussions of colonial rule: the new social structures', 'section_title': 'The new social structures', 'content': 'However, we find that even in the Muslim emirates of Northern Nigeria where it would appear there was a harmony of interests between the colonial power and the emirs, the union between the European and indigenous administrative systems was never organic. The result was that in some aspects of the life of a colony such as the purely secular the two systems could work hand in hand, while in some others they would work independently and, sometimes, at cross purposes.
One other social impact of foreign rule which was noticeable quite early in the colonial period was the general depression of the status of Africans. Colonialism superimposed on the pre-existing class structure of the continent at least an extra layer of leaders and pacesetters. In East Africa where it encouraged Asian immigration, colonialism in fact superimposed two classes. In each colony Europeans had the monopoly of political, economic and educational power, except in East Africa where a fraction of the economic power fell into the hands of Asians. In this situation the Africans became the underprivileged and looked up to the Europeans, and at times to the Asians, for leadership and example.
This structure of social relationship was shored up with a bogus racial theory which sought to arrange the different branches of the human family in a hierarchical order of civilization with the Africans (the Negroes) occupying the bottom of the ladder while the Europeans (whites) occupied the top. In Southern Africa, in particular, where white settlers found themselves locked in conflict with numerically superior Bantu peoples, the racial theory was especially stringent, with the authority of the Holy Bible being wrongly used to reinforce the presumed social implications of pseudo-Darwinism. For the Negroes in particular the theory postulated a degree of cultural barrenness which made it necessary and possible to explain their history and social evolution in terms of the Hamitic impact.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.663, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}]

[{'id': 328, 'article_title': 'Abeokuta, Okeodan, and Addo', 'full_section_title': 'Abeokuta, Okeodan, and Addo', 'last_edit_date': '01-01-1864', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_02_1864#article-16', 'issue_date': '23_02_1864', 'content': 'We ought, too, it seems, according to them, to have helped them to destroy the Ibadans, that they might have preserved their slave hunting-grounds. Okeodan is now a dreadful thorn in their side. Okeodan under British protection—a town so far in the interior—is a deadly rival to Abeokuta. Our Badagry friend quite confirms what our Lagos friend expressed in the important paper we published last month, as to the great wisdom and advantage of Lieutenant-Governor Glover's policy in receiving Okeodan, &c., under the protection of this country. We repeat, Lieut.-Governor Glover "did the State good service."

Our clever and well-informed friend enters at length upon the subject of this new protectorate, and of the efforts—the vain efforts—making by the Egbas to induce the people of Okeodan to undo what they have done. But we are compelled to defer the remainder of his information and comments until our March number. Lagos—our youngest colony—has our especial sympathy. And all that tends to increase its powers for usefulness in the civilization of that important portion of Africa to which it, by situation, appertains, is of corresponding interest in our eyes. And, despite all the grievous sins of the Egbas, there is a nucleus of Christianity in Abeokuta that cannot fail eventually, we think, to bring Lagos and Abeokuta into an union for the spread of civilization that will be productive of very important results.'}, {'id': 3651, 'article_title': 'The Quarrel of the Ibadans and the Egbas', 'full_section_title': 'The Quarrel of the Ibadans and the Egbas', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_09_1878#article-13', 'issue_date': '02_09_1878', 'content': '

and we hope and believe that some enlightened Administrator at Lagos will succeed in arranging a basis of reconciliation and enduring friendship between antagonists, whose only rivalry ought now to be which shall make the most rapid progress in industrial development and civilization. If, as stated, the only desire of the Ibadans is to procure constant and abundant supplies of arms and ammunition, not for self-defence, but for wars of aggression and conquest, and with the fixed intention and hope of ultimately destroying Abeokuta; we think it should be a matter for serious consideration by the British authorities at Lagos, whether in the interests, not only of Lagos as the great seaport of those countries, but in the also of the whole population of the Egba and Yoruba territories, they should not adopt a decided policy for the maintenance of peace, and make that policy known to all the parties interested. Lagos cannot be advantaged in any way by the destruction of the Egbas by the Ibadans. Every attack by the Ibadans on the Egba farms is an attack on the prosperity of Lagos. It seems to us, therefore, that the time has come when the Government at Lagos should notify to the chiefs and people at Ibadan that all unprovoked attacks by the latter on the Egba farms; and all attempts against the territorial integrity of Abeokuta, will be not only displeasing to the government at Lagos, but will, if persisted in, be at length regarded as acts of hostility against Lagos itself; that in an unprovoked war of aggression by Ibadan upon Abeokuta, the latter would, in case of necessity, be assisted by Her Majesty's Government at Lagos. It is surely time that the Queen's Government at Lagos should exercise its just influence in interior disputes that so gravely compromise those commercial interests on the prosperity of which that of Lagos itself depends. The key-note of civilization, peace, and prosperity in those countries must be sounded from Lagos; and it is not worthy in a Government carried on there in the name of the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland, that this key-note should be only so faintly struck as to be, as it has hitherto been, scarcely audible. That Government must adopt a policy distinct, stable, enlightened, and understood by the interior peoples. We do not see any secure basis on which such a policy can be founded and built up, but that of peace, friendship, and goodwill with and towards Abeokuta, and the promise of efficient aid to the latter, if necessary, in the event of unprovoked attack from Ibadan. Her Majesty's Government has remonstrated with the King of Dahomey as regards his oft-repeated attacks upon Abeokuta, one at least of which would seem to have been made by direct invitation of Ibadan; and it will only be a carrying out of the same policy to make similar remonstrances with the latter. If there be a perfectly friendly understanding with Abeokuta on the part of the Lagos government, with a frank declaration of such a policy as we have pointed to, we cannot believe that there would be any difficulty in arranging the question of transit dues between Abeokuta and Ibadan. If, as asserted, the objection on the part of the Egbas to force intercourse on the part of the Yorubas with Lagos, is one derived from the natural instinct of self-preservation, that objection will disappear when once Abeokuta becomes assured that, let Ibadan import whatever quantity of arms and ammunition she may, she will not be permitted to use them for despoiling and destroying Abeokuta. We should then also hope to see a perfect and entire accord between the Lagos Government and the Egba authorities for improving the land communications of Abeokuta with Lagos. The distance between the two places ought to be accomplished within the short space of a few hours, both for passengers and goods. Then, and never until then, will the Egba countries make that progress which such fertile countries, inhabited by so industrial a population, ought to make. All our views, aims, and desires concerning them, since Lagos became a possession of the British Crown, have been in this direction; and we yet hope to see them realized. It will appear at once, to all who are interested in the discussion and settlement of matters so vital as regards the commercial prosperity of Lagos, that the Porto Novo Question cannot be overlooked. It is time it was settled in the way desired by the enlightened portion of the Lagos community, native and European. The supplies of ammunition which enabled the Ibadans to commence their late raids in Abeokuta territory—raids, which we rejoice to hear, have, in many instances, been vigorously repulsed—were obtained from Porto Novo by a large armed body of Ibadans, who, either with the connivance, or because of the small power of resistance of the king of that place, plundered the stores of English and other merchants of all that they chose to require. The present efforts of the Ibadans to make a road of their own through Egba territory to Porto Novo, are efforts to enable them to repeat that plundering operation whenever their marauding necessities may require fresh supplies. We showed, some months ago, in a leading article in our journal, how indispensable it had now become that Porto Novo should be united with Lagos under British government; and the conviction then expressed could only be confirmed by the fact of the persistent attacks of the Ibadans on Egba farms lying on the line of their coveted road to Porto Novo. They would no longer have the same object in making, or desiring to make this road if Porto Novo and Lagos were under the same rule—a rule which has both the will and the power to prevent such depredations as those committed by the Ibadans in Porto Novo. We cannot doubt that the annexation of Porto Novo by amicable contract and arrangement with the Native authority of that place is under the consideration of Her Majesty's Government, who must feel the same desire that we do, that the enormities there practised should be put an end to, as well as that British property there should be freed from its present proved liability to plunder. Having "put their hand to the plough" in the annexation of Lagos, which, notwithstanding the occasional errors of its local government, has put an end to very great evils, and brought in a very great amount of good, they ought not now to draw back or hesitate when, as in the matter of Porto Novo, the need is so pressing, and the interests of humanity and civilizing commerce alike demand their immediate action.'}, {'id': 6304, 'article_title': 'Leader', 'full_section_title': 'Leader', 'last_edit_date': '02-01-1893', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1893#article-6', 'issue_date': '01_02_1893', 'content': 'WE ARE MOST PLEASED to be able to record that the difficulties between the British Government and the Egbas, which, during the past year or so have been the fruitful source of all manner of trouble to the commercial prosperity of Lagos, seem at last to have received a satisfactory solution. His Excellency Governor Carter early in January arrived at Abeokuta, the Egba capital, and was received with all fitting honour at the entrance to the town by delegates from the principal chiefs. On the 10th there was a grand assembly of chiefs and people to welcome the Governor of Lagos. In the course of the palaver, Governor Carter expressed the pleasure he felt at seeing the chiefs, and declared that the occasion was an important one for Abeokuta and Lagos, and marked a new era in the history of the country. His welcome was a sign of the removal of the former suspicion and distrust of the Government of Lagos, and must be regarded as substituting for them confidence and goodwill. The reply on behalf of the Egba chiefs was characteristic and to the point: "The whole Egba nation welcomes you. We thank you for your truthfulness and justice, and manifest our joy and appreciation by having this large assembly to greet you. Welcome to Abeokuta!" Things having been arranged satisfactorily so far, the conclusion of a new Treaty between the British authorities

and the Egba chiefs followed as a matter of course. This Treaty was agreed to on the 18th, though up to the time of our going to press a complete official copy was not obtainable. But, doubtless, it follows the lines usual in such cases with such modifications as the circumstances of the case necessitate. It, of course, declares that peace and friendship exist between the subjects of Queen Victoria and the Egbas. Any difference which may arise is to be referred to the Governor of Lagos for settlement. Complete freedom of trade is established between the Egba country and Lagos. In view of the injury to commerce resulting from the closing of roads, the King and his authorities declare that no roads shall in future be closed without the consent of the Governor. The King and his authorities pledged themselves to use every means to foster and promote trade in the Egba country and Lagos, and to afford complete protection and assistance to traders. They also promise to abolish the practice of human sacrifice existing in Ijone township.'}]
tat_extra: [{'document_title': 'Laying the Foundation-stone of Holy Trinity Church, Ebute Ero, Lagos, West Africa.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Thursday, the 1st day of November, 1877, will long be remembered in Lagos. On the afternoon of that day hundreds of persons assembled to witness the great event that was taking place. In December, 1851, Commodore (now Admiral) Bruce, by order of Lord Palmerston\'s Government, brought King Akitoye from his exile, and after attacking the island of Lagos successfully by some steamers and boats of the British squadron which entered the river, the results were that the usurper, King Kosoko, fled to Epe, in the Jebu territory, on the night of the 28th December, 1851; and on the 1st of January, 1852, King Akitoye was put on the throne of Lagos. He made a treaty with the British Government, and a paragraph reads thus: "To open liberty to missionaries or ministers of the Gospel of any nation to enter Lagos, and follow their vocation of spreading the knowledge and doctrines of Christianity, and extending the benefits of civilization." (*Vide* *Payne\'s Lagos Almanack, 1877,* pp. 96-97: Treaty signed on board H.M.S. Penelope, flagship of the Admiral.)', 'last_edit_date': '1877-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_01_1878#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.714, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Should the peace of the Yoruba and Egba countries thus become firmly established through the exercise of British influence at Ibadan and Abeokuta, a great prosperity—a large and constantly increasing trade—is in store for Lagos, and not this alone. We believe it to be impossible for the natives visiting Lagos, consequently, to remain uninfluenced by the improvements which European civilisation will have effected, and be effecting, in Lagos. That town must be Abeokuta; that power must be the power of authorities and people concentrated at Abeokuta. Possessed by these views and feelings, from which we have never deviated through all the troubles and disputes between Abeokuta and Lagos, and between the Egba and British authorities in these two places—troubles and disputes originating in mutual misconception, and fostered by interested malevolence and individual ambitions, interests, and hatreds—we have waited patiently until the storms of passion and the vapours of distrust should pass away. We hope and believe that these have now ever passed away. We learn with a satisfaction which it is not possible for us to find words adequately to describe, that the long conflicting interests in Abeokuta have now become reconciled, and that one generally recognized authority is now acknowledged there. This is a most important step in the right direction for assisting in the realization of our plans for the good of Abeokuta and its industrious, persevering people. We want Abeokuta to become strong—so defensively, not offensively, strong that no kingdom, or tribe, or people, or state shall dare to attack or seek to injure her or her people. We want absolute security for the Egba farms, that the labourer may work in full and entire confidence that he shall enjoy the fruit of his labours. But it is time that Abeokuta, distant only sixty or seventy miles from Lagos, should become so strong that she may command immunity from attack, whether from Dahomey or any other quarter, not merely by the good offices of the friendly British Government, though these must always be of importance to her, but by her own power and strength. Every reduction of even one hour in the duration of journey between Lagos and Abeokuta is an added strength to the Egba capital. How greatly, then, will Abeokuta be strengthened when the journey between it and Lagos, the conveyance of produce, passengers, and goods, shall be reduced to four or five hours only! It is not easy to realize in one's mind the immense advantage that will accrue to Abeokuta and to the whole Egba and Yoruba countries by the establishment of such ready means of access between Abeokuta and Lagos. There must, however, now be educated Africans in Abeokuta who can so far realize the advantages in their minds as to enable them to show and explain and to convince the native authorities and people in Abeokuta of those advantages. As regards Lagos, we can scarcely conceive the necessity of effort to convince any one there. Lagos can only become a grand, rich town by large and prosperous trade; and every increased facility of transit in the interior, and from the interior to Lagos, every additional security to farming and other industrial operations at and around Abeokuta, which serves to increase the supply of exportable produce to Lagos and the consequent demand for British manufactured and other goods, becomes necessarily a factor in future Lagos grandeur, prosperity, and wealth. On the score of increased health alone for the people of the interior and Lagos, both of which would be equally benefited in this important matter, rapid communication between Abeokuta and Lagos is so desirable, that every thinking man ought to be ready to make considerable sacrifices, if necessary, to secure the advantage. When our mind dwells on the subject of the proposed road and its beneficial influences, the prospect opening before us is so pleasing and so grand, that we cannot help deploring the time did not sooner arrive for this onward step, so that we might hope to live to record the interesting and wonderful results. We see Abeokuta in immediate communication with Lagos, with railway working, and steamboat service from Gaiun so improved as to reduce the journey to three hours. We see Abeokuta so strong and wealthy through that communication and constant friendly alliance with Lagos, that Ibadan and every populous town throughout Yoruba are begging of Abeokuta's rich men to help them with money to make roads from their towns to Abeokuta, so that their people may bring their produce to it, and go down themselves to Lagos and behold the sea. We see produce and people pouring into Abeokuta from Rabba, and even from Kano and Kooka; Abeokuta having become the great emporium to which all the produce of interior and surrounding countries comes, to be exchanged there for the European and other goods and manufactures brought also there to be exchanged for that produce. It will not, therefore, be matter for surprise that, with our deep and ardent desire for progress in Africa, and the happiness and well-being of its people, we should have determined to make every possible effort for introducing this wonder-working agent of advanced civilization into the Egba country. A road from such a place as Lagos to such a place as Abeokuta—with a large population at each extremity and around the interior terminus— in a country where the people are so given to industry that enormous quantities of produce may be safely calculated upon, cannot fail to give adequate returns to investors, who will certainly benefit themselves while conferring incalculable advantages upon a most interesting people—a nation composed of the united remnants of many formerly very large tribes, the great masses of which perished in the wars provoked by the foreign slave-traders who were in search of victims at Lagos, or shipped thence (with exception of the many poor exhausted wretches who served as food for the great shoals of sharks in the Lagos waters) as slaves for the supply of the plantations in Jamaica, Demerara, Porto Rico, Cuba, the United States, and Brazil. If, as stated, the only desire of the Ibadans is to procure constant and abundant supplies of arms and ammunition, not for self-defence, but for wars of aggression and conquest, and with the fixed intention and hope of ultimately destroying Abeokuta; we think it should be a matter for serious consideration by the British authorities at Lagos, whether in the interests, not only of Lagos as the great seaport of those countries, but in the also of the whole population of the Egba and Yoruba territories, they should not adopt a decided policy for the maintenance of peace, and make that policy known to all the parties interested. Lagos cannot be advantaged in any way by the destruction of the Egbas by the Ibadans. Every attack by the Ibadans on the Egba farms is an attack on the prosperity of Lagos. It is surely time that the Queen\'s Government at Lagos should exercise its just influence in interior disputes that so gravely compromise those commercial interests on the prosperity of which that of Lagos itself depends. The key-note of civilization, peace, and prosperity in those countries must be sounded from Lagos; and it is not worthy in a Government carried on there in the name of the Queen of Great Britain and Ireland, that this key-note should be only so faintly struck as to be, as it has hitherto been, scarcely audible. That Government must adopt a policy distinct, stable, enlightened, and understood by the interior peoples. We do not see any secure basis on which such a policy can be founded and built up, but that of peace, friendship, and goodwill with and towards Abeokuta, and the promise of efficient aid to the latter, if necessary, in the event of unprovoked attack from Ibadan. It will appear at once, to all who are interested in the discussion and settlement of matters so vital as regards the commercial prosperity of Lagos, that the Porto Novo Question cannot be overlooked. The supplies of ammunition which enabled the Ibadans to commence their late raids in Abeokuta territory—raids, which we rejoice to hear, have, in many instances, been vigorously repulsed—were obtained from Porto Novo by a large armed body of Ibadans, who, either with the connivance, or because of the small power of resistance of the king of that place, plundered the stores of English and other merchants of all that they chose to require. Those who have suffered so greatly from the loss of trade during the past two years have had "consolations" of late. We cannot say that friendly relations with the Abeokutans are yet re-established, though there seems great reason to believe they soon will be. But the produce that has poured into Lagos since the siege of Ikorodu was raised and the Ibadan road was opened has fully justified all the expectations formed by those who advocated the establishment of a British colony at Lagos on the ground that it would lead to its becoming, in the course of a few years, a grand emporium for the whole of the Yoruba countries. When trading relations shall be again restored with Abeokuta, those who have most condemned the efforts of the friends of material advancement and civilisation in Africa, who advocated the extension and increase of British power and influence at certain points on the Coast, will find that we were right and they were wrong, and that we were working for their profit while seeking the good of Africa.\n\nAnd this entire re-establishment of trading relations with Abeokuta seems to have been at hand when the last mail left that place for England. the opening of the roads to traffic when a portion of this debt should have been paid; that goods going up in future from Lagos should be without British protection—all goods having to be bought by the Egbas in or near Lagos—so that the interior traffic and commerce of the country should be in their own hands; the only difficulty with the Abeokutans seeming to be that they could not in justice to the merchants, who had come among them in good faith, require them to leave so long as they did not commit any offence, and showed a due respect for their laws.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-07-09', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1865#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'GOVERNMENT OF ABEOKUTA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "which nations cannot undertake the works indispensable to material development, were it not that wasteful heathen customs still throw their impoverishing shade over them, undoing frequently in a month or two all that it has taken some persistent individual a whole lifetime to accomplish. In our last we gave important news from Abeokuta—important, at least, as regards the great Egba nation and the neighbouring British settlement of Lagos. We announce the death of the Bashorun of the town, the man who had for some years, in default of a king, exercised the chief power there. For seventeen years he had been in this position, to which he had risen by daring and energy, but the influence of old age had of late years made itself injuriously felt in his character, causing him to become vacillating and unstable, and enfeebling his mind and arm for government. This ought not to astonish anyone when we record his age. He was ninety-three years old when death removed him from among his people. If he had been only sixty-three instead of ninety-three, we should never have heard of such scenes as those enacted in October, 1867, when the Christian places of worship were pillaged, and missionaries who had laboured there during many years retired to Lagos. The death of the Bashorun is not, therefore, to be regarded as a calamity, for the Egbas, who will now again come under the rule of a king—Ayekon, of Ake, of whom report speaks as possessing qualities which inspire a reasonable hope that peace, prosperity, and industrial development will shed their blessings over the country subject to his authority, in the exercise of which he will be zealously assisted by the kings and chiefs forming the lately-constituted Egba Board of Management, which we may regard as a species of executive council of state, and which will, we hope, prove instrumental in establishing and consolidating institutions calculated to obtain for the Egbas internal tranquillity and external respect. Abeokuta, even in its comparative infancy, has proved an insurmountable barrier to the inroads and depredations of the Dahomans on that side of the country, as Ashantee has on the other; and we shall not be at all surprised if, in the course of a few years, such a people should no longer be content merely to resist and defeat the Dahomans when they invade their territory and come before the walls of their town, but, in a plan of enlightened self-defence, so bring the intermediate towns and peoples into voluntary obedience or friendly union, as to enable them to assume the offensive, break in pieces the already-enfeebled Dahoman power, which has wasted its strength in the bloodthirsty expeditions of its kings, and give something like assured peace to that naturally rich and fertile, but long oppressed and devastated portion of Africa. For all this it is necessary that there should be a true and lasting friendship between this people and the British settlement of Lagos. The British Government has entirely repudiated all desire of domination in that part of Africa. In Lagos, it can and will confer essential advantages upon Abeokuta and other Egba towns, and the Yoruba countries generally—the advantages of a secure and improved outlet for the products of the soil—the advantages of showing at its very door those improvements which civilisation introduces, and which tend so much toward the welfare, the happiness, and strength of a community—the advantages of having a wealthy neighbour able and willing to assist a rising, energetic people in its early and necessarily painful and suspicious efforts at consolidation, amelioration, and advancement. And as among the changes absolutely indispensable among the Egbas themselves to their progress and wealth, we hope that under a new and more enlightened government than they have hitherto enjoyed, their king and his assisting council may succeed in inducing them to abandon that impoverishing custom by which all that was the late property of the dead is dissipated in foolish ceremonies and debasing excesses, leaving his family and descendants stripped and penniless. Such, our correspondent, who informs us of the late Bashorun's death, seems to have believed would unhappily be the fate of the deceased ruler's property and family. The increasing influence of Christianity would put an end to such pernicious follies and excesses, and it is only by their being put an end to that Abeokuta can become really great and powerful, in presence of the reflex of European civilisation brought at Lagos to its very doors. In the welfare, therefore, of the Egbas as a nation, as well as in that of its individuals, as men and women who desire happiness here and eternal felicity hereafter, we hope and pray that the blessed and blessing Christian work which has been so happily begun may revive, be strengthened, and ere long entirely prevail among them.", 'last_edit_date': '1868-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1868#article-18', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.701, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Tribute to the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': "And although a state of circumstances which never ought to have existed has temporarily affected the trade of Lagos, and causes losses that we deeply regret; still, the daily increasing value of the soil of Lagos, even under the disadvantage of such interruption of trade, shows how, resting on the immovable basis of England's power, civilization is advancing, with its accompanying results. There is stagnation of trade, but property which had value has increased in value fourfold; and much that was valueless has acquired, and is daily increasing in, value. Notwithstanding the errors and administrative excesses of governors unused to govern, a warm breath of civilization is floating out of Lagos upon the surrounding countries. The toils of civilization are upon them. With Lagos a British colony, they have no escape. Lagos is already undergoing a great change. With the disappearance of native thatched roofs, a great deal of native filth, and many native irregularities, has also taken compulsory leave. The Africans are an observant people. The Egbas, who have lent themselves more readily to missionary instruction than any other natives, will ere long desire to make their towns equal with renewed and embellished Lagos. Under encouragement from Lagos, roads from the interior, for the passage of persons and goods, will ere long be made. All that we regret is, that the territory of Lagos did not incontestibly extend to Aro, the place of embarkation on the river, three miles from Abeokuta. There is abundant territory for Abeokuta on the other side. This would have been a real blessing for Abeokuta. Supported by the immediate proximity of British authority, the native Christians would have obtained the supremacy, and progress would have been rapid. But though delayed, it must be entered upon. We are near enough to render that certain. Our African neighbours cannot isolate themselves, and cannot remain unprogressive, in the presence of our power at Lagos. Every step they make in progress will increase production and trade. And we feel convinced that, within a very short time, our Lagos friends who have condemned us for having, as they believe, exercised considerable influence in producing annexation, will rejoice with us that England has, in this instance, been true to her real mission, and snatched another land from the filth and darkness of heathen rule, to shed upon and from it the glorious light of her Christian civilization.", 'last_edit_date': '1863-11-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_11_1863#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.699, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE YORUBA COUNTRIES', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'We have never ceased to assert that, although some trade may be done at points of the coast where there is no established British authority, the presence of a European and Christian civilization in power is indispensable to the advancement of native Africa. We seem to have a new and striking instance in support of this at Lagos, for the erection of which into a British colony we, among others, have been so much and so greatly condemned, not only by those whose mercantile operations were unfortunately rendered for a time less profitable, but by others who, though unsurpassed in their desires for the national, social, and religious improvement of the Africans, think that this could be effected solely by the influence of missionaries, in conjunction with the European commerce which may be carried on to some extent where they are present. A considerable trade was carried on at Lagos while it was under native rule and British protection. But that trade was really created by the latter; because until Great Britain had obtained the defending and nominally, controlling power there, Lagos had been one of the great seats of that foreign slave-trade the history of the active ravages of which in western Africa is now, we hope, nearly closed. But though legitimate trade of some considerable importance sprang up and was successfully carried on at Lagos under the new order of things, the influence of Lagos as a country was not on the side of Christian civilization. The presence of the representatives of the protecting power alone prevented the slave-trade, which continued to be carried on in driblets through Porto Novo and Badagry, from becoming rampant as before. Lagos, as a native power, being more or less at variance with the other native rule on the mainland shores of the Lagoon, had its chief commercial relations with the interior at Abeokuta, which there was facility of access by river; and its commerce was augmented by the palm oil trade of Porto Novo and Badagry. Abeokuta was the only bright spot in those dark parts of the world. Liberated slaves, natives of that country, educated and instructed in the rudiments of the Christian faith, returned there from Sierra Leone. European missionary establishments followed them; and, although paganism still ruled, it became gradually restrained in some of its great enormities by British influences thus introduced. But it was pagan at core, and fond of little wars wherein slaves might be taken for labour, enjoyment, or sale through Dahomey. In virtue, however, of its continuous friendly relations with Lagos—the natural shipping port for the whole of these countries—of the presence of a considerable missionary body, and of many active Sierra Leone traders in it, it became the emporium of the interior, and the great road of traffic passed through it. "If you wish to make me happy get from between me and the sun," said the ancient Greek. "Get from between me and the sea," is the continual cry of the interior of Africa to the populations intervening between it and the great waters. It was because they would not allow free access to the sea that the Dahomans fought and pressed forward until they destroyed all the peoples which barred their access to the coast, at Wydah and neighbouring ports. It is because the sea with all its contingent advantages is there, that Ashantee is the irreconcilable enemy of the Fantee tribes lying between it and Cape Coast. In the same way Abeokuta stood between the large populations of Yoruba and Lagos. As the only open road for Yoruban and the far interior produce had been through Abeokuta, with great advantage to the latter place, which desired to take toll of all that passed by it, the Abeokutans declared that it should be the only road, and determined to use all their power to maintain this, and gratify at the time their slave-acquiring propensities. With the establishment of British rule and authority in the colony of Lagos, all the petty rivalries and hatreds between Lagos and the mainland rulers on the Lagoons were doomed to disappear. The great town of Ibadan, with double the population of Abeokuta, which had sold produce and received supplies in driblets through Abeokuta, desired to have free access to Lagos and its important markets by the more direct road of Ikorodu. The authorities of Lagos saw their duty clearly in this matter. The present Lieutenant-Governor, Captain Glover, had a personal acquaintance with Yoruba and the Niger countries beyond, and was deeply penetrated with the enormous advantages that might accrue, not only commercially to Lagos, but as regards the development of resources and spread of Christian civilization in Yoruba, if its large populations could obtain and maintain a free road through Ikorodu to the Lagos lagoon. When the Egbas, therefore, after the retirement of the Ibadans in the late war, laid siege to Ikorodu, they were warned by the Governor of Lagos that unless they made themselves masters of it, and established their sovereignty over that part within a given time, they must abandon the enterprise. They did not make themselves masters—they were repulsed in every attempt, but they remained in force in an entrenched camp, and stopped the way. Notice was given them to retire—they mocked at it—they defied the power that requested their departure—and Minie rifles and Congreve rockets in disciplined hands were sent over from Lagos to teach them that Great Britain only advises and requires what she has power to enforce. The rifles and rockets did their appointed work. The road from Ibadan to Lagos, through Ikorodu, was permanently opened; and a lesson was taught—an important lesson, which may bring to that part of Africa results more beneficial than language can describe. They were taught that, since Great Britain is in Lagos, war in the adjacent countries cannot, and shall not, be carried on without her license and permission. We refer our readers to the intelligence under the head of Lagos. War—war—war—little wars for slaves, and for little objects—was the curse of those as of other portions of native Africa. And if these can be permanently put an end to, as we believe that through the influence of Lagos—British Lagos—they will, the great bar to the material development of the rich Egba and Yoruba countries will be removed, and a free access will be given to the propagation of Christianity, and to the influence of the example of civilization which Lagos, daily cleansing and improving, will present to every native trader from the interior who may visit its markets. We feel our old conviction that colonial Lagos would prove a mighty agent in the work of African regeneration was a just one, and that its influence is about to make itself most beneficially felt through the vast regions with respect to which it occupies so important a position.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-08-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_08_1865#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'ABEOKUTA AND LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The letter we have now published (p. 36) on "What Caused the Heathen Uprising in Abeokuta on Sunday, October 13, 1867," brings the whole question of the unsettled and most unsatisfactory state of relations between Lagos and Abeokuta again prominently before us. The sale and gift of lands at Ebute Meta by the Lagos Government, constituting as this does an absolute claim and assumption of British authority over that portion of the main land, is a measure of such extreme importance as bearing upon the present and future relations between the British colony of Lagos and the native government of Abeokuta, that nothing short of the most imperious necessity, and the most indisputable and indefeasible claim, can possibly justify such proceedings. There is no portion of the West Coast at which the development of productive resources and the increase of commerce, may be so rapid as in the Abeokuta Territories (with Yoruba generally) and Lagos, provided there be a constantly good and friendly understanding and amicable relations between Lagos and Abeokuta. But for this it is essential that nothing should be done on the part of the Island Government to wound the just susceptibilities, or aggravate the unfortunate distrust of the Abeokutans, as regards British encroachment. The progress of Christian civilisation and material development in the Yoruba countries and primarily among the Aku people, and the increase of the trade of Lagos, are desired results necessarily bound up together and inseparably united. It is not for the permanent mercantile interests of Lagos that she should be mixed up with the wars and disputes of the interior, except as a great civilised pacificator—as the representative of British Christian civilisation acting for the amelioration of adjacent heathen lands. But if Lagos holds absolute possession on the main land, she can scarcely fail to be involved in such native wars and disputes; and it must be expected that questions will continually arise to disturb the friendly intercourse of Lagos with the interior. We regard this matter of the present and future relations of Lagos with the main-land people, and especially with Abeokuta, as one of such very great importance, that we feel it to be our duty to solicit for it the prompt and especial attention of the Governor-in-Chief. Among the gross neglects of duty of Governor Blackall we look upon his conduct as regards this important matter, as one of the most serious, and at the same time, most irritating to native susceptibilities and suspicions. We see with pleasure that the Governor of Lagos has been lately invited to Sierra Leone by the Governor-in-Chief; doubtless for those explanations as regards the Lagos Government which could scarcely be fully given without a personal interview; and as the facts, real or supposed, as viewed by the local Lagos Executive, and the views of that Executive, will now have been brought under the keen and impartial mental scrutiny of Sir Arthur Kennedy, we look forward with hope and confidence to some action of the Governor-in-Chief, that shall lead to a speedy placing of the relations of Lagos with Abeokuta, and *vice versa*, on a just and friendly footing, such as will tend to the permanent reciprocal advantage of the inhabitants of the British colony and of the adjacent native territories.', 'last_edit_date': '1868-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1868#article-22', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Dahoman Raid on Abeokuta', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'capital, in the latter,—we still look to the Egbas as a people endowed with natural gifts, which, if properly directed, could scarcely fail to make them mighty instruments in the spread of that Christian civilization in Africa, without which there can be no satisfactory progress there, no rising from the debasement produced by ages after ages of ignorance, and a childish and cruel superstition. Oh, that the true light would shine on those dark lands! Oh, that a nation should there be born in a day! This will, of course, follow the glorious second advent of the Great Messiah, the Crucified of Calvary, yet King of kings and Lord of lords; but we would fain have seen some small approach to it, some faint day-dawn glimmerings of it, in our own time. We hope for it even now, and hoping for, even as earnestly desiring it, our deep interest in the Egbas as a people is unimpaired. We do not regard it as a mere accident, that among the Africans delivered by British cruisers from the power of the foreign slave-trader, and subsequently introduced to the knowledge of the English language by education, and of Christianity by the teaching of zealous missionaries, the Akus should predominate in numbers; or that (so far as our knowledge on this point at present extends) they and the Eboes, their near neighbours in Western Africa, should have afforded superior evidence of the capability of the African to attain to and receive both secular and Christian enlightenment. We believe that God, in His providence, has so overruled events for special results; and shall not therefore be surprised to see some combined efforts, by these instruments thus specially prepared, for bringing such enlightenment to the native mind within the territories peopled by their race, as may prepare the way, among other things, to the adoption by the authorities of Abeokuta of those means of defence and security which the advanced civilization of Europe can and is ready to supply. The security of Abeokuta, its entire delivery from the cruel pest of Dahomey, ought to be an object near to the heart of all of them; and we often feel surprised that they have done so little hitherto, as a body, to bring their education, their enlightenment, their Christianity, to bear in an operatively beneficial way upon those of whom we have been writing. There are two objects that they ought to strive for, constantly and untiringly—and will so strive for, if their education and Christianity be worth anything—beyond those blessed individual influences on character and principle which ought to flow immediately from them. These two things are, the obtaining for Abeokuta, and the territory between it and Dahomey, that delivery and security without which nothing permanently beneficial can be hoped for; and the forming an easy and speedy land communication between Abeokuta and a point on the waters toward Lagos, to which the navigation is at all times open. These two things are intimately allied, for if such easy and rapid communication existed between Abeokuta and Lagos, it would be such an element of power to Abeokuta that the Dahomans would never thereafter think for a single moment of disturbing its industrial activity by their atrocious raids. We urge it as a duty upon all those who are connected with that country by ties of blood and birth, to employ combined as well as individual efforts for the accomplishment of this great end. Every one of those who have received the blessing of education ought to be an apostle of progress, and it will not be creditable to them should they still remain inert as regards great public objects, and only careful and enterprising in matters concerning their own personal advantage.', 'last_edit_date': '1875-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1875#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.694, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CHURCH TOWER AND CLOCK IN LAGOS.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Influence to be exercised by it, that must produce incalculable blessings throughout those wide-spread territories, for the abundant production of which this once dark seat of a hideous slave trade, offers by its now well-filled port a ready and advantageous outlet. It is only ten years since this interesting little island was under native rule, and a sort of British protection, which had been afforded with the object of entirely suppressing the slave trade that was still a devastating agent in neighbouring countries. It was found, however, to be impossible to prevent this altogether, while the island should continue under native rule; some little slave trade was still secretly carried on with the native mainland; and as the actual ruler of the country was only so by reason of the efficacious protection afforded by a resident British agent, with British ships of war within call, it was wisely and humanely determined by the British Government, in which the power and influence of Lord Palmerston were then supreme, that the native King should retire upon a pension, and the settlement be made a British one. We were an ardent promoter of this change, and incurred great odium in consequence, among merchants who, under British protection, there carried on a successful trade without payment of the duties exacted where British authorities held sway; and among educated African traders, who but in too many cases abandoned in Lagos those restraints which Christian civilisation imposed on them in Sierra Leone. Lagos was then a filthy, pestiferous place, peculiarly fatal to Europeans. Ten years, only ten years, and what a change has been accomplished! At no other place in Africa has civilising progress been so rapid, or shown such irrepressible energy. Mistakes were made in the early days of British rule, which led for a time to an entire alienation of the powerful Egba nations on the mainland; eventuating in hostilities that for some time paralysed trade, and left bitter seeds of distrust in the native mind in Abeokuta and elsewhere. By a wiser policy, however, during the last four or five years, Administrator Glover has done much to redeem the past in that respect; abstaining from everything that could give rise to further distrust or suspicion. We are sorry sometimes to think that he never can obtain the confidence and goodwill of the Egba people; and that, in consequence, many works that would shed additional lustre upon his name, can never be effected by him. And here we think it well to take advantage of this opportunity to impress upon him the necessity, in the interests of Lagos, of not incautiously recommencing efforts such as for opening communication with Ibadan, &c., they may arouse anew the old hostile feelings, and that can only serve to retard the realisation of those useful objects which he no doubt has in view, but which we are persuaded the interior natives never can be brought to assent to and co-operate in, until Lagos shall possess an elected Legislative Council. When this right shall be accorded to her, the presence and influence of those educated African merchants and traders, civilised and Christian, which Lagos already has in no small number among her citizens, may and will enable the then Government of Lagos to overcome all suspicion and animosity, and to show Egbas, Ijebus, Ijeshas, and all concerned, that Lagos desires the introduction of such and such works among them, not from motives of ambition or lust of dominion, but for the mutual and reciprocal advancement of Lagos and the interior. That elected Legislative Council cannot be long denied to Lagos. Her progress is too rapid to permit of this. Her revenues, from duties on imports, are now, we believe, between 40,000l. and 50,000l. a-year. They will, no doubt, yearly increase. She has well-laid-out streets, presenting a striking contrast to the former agglomeration of the vilest class of African huts. Those streets are lighted. Sanitary improvements have made her a healthy place of residence, even for Europeans, if they will abstain from the indulgence of those destructive propensities which may be justly said to have dug by far the greater number of British graves along the West Coast. And having churches and chapels, which have been for the most part built by funds raised in Lagos itself, she is now making an effort for a church tower, with its public clock. We admire this public spirit among her educated African traders; and this particular manifestation of it has our warmest sympathy. We do not offer pecuniary aid; nor do we ask any one in England, unless he be a Lagos man absent for a time from his country, to give any aid. We are jealous for the reputation of Lagos. She is able now to do such works for her embellishment and convenience with her own money, and she will do it; and if the list of contributors be furnished to us when the necessary sum shall be all subscribed, we will immortalise them in our columns. Meanwhile we wish them heartily Godspeed; and we desire that those sincere friends of Africa who do exist in England, should take comfort in seeing what God has already wrought by the civilising and Christianising agencies of Great Britain, in a place where but a few years since the waters were daily defiled by the poor murdered victims of the brutal and abominable slave trade.', 'last_edit_date': '1871-09-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1871#article-14', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.695, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'OUR WEST AFRICAN RAILWAYS.—THE LAGOS-ABEOKUTA LINE', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The Egbas of Abeokuta can run down to Lagos in the morning, and return to their homes, if they so will, on the evening of the same day; when their oil, their cotton, their kernels, their beni-seed, their ivory, and a variety of other produce now unutilized, can find its way in one day from the purchasing merchant in Abeokuta to the shipping warehouses in Lagos,—the peoples beyond will clamour for the enjoyment of similar privileges, and lend their energies to link themselves with the great Egba trunk line. The charm of increased facilities for human intercourse is contagious. Man only wraps himself up contentedly in isolation, and glories in it, and in the local ignorance and prejudices which it begets and fosters, until something better is placed within his reach. We can imagine a man born blind to be contented within himself, though somewhat curious as to what others see; but once open his eyes, and methinks he would desire to embrace the whole universe in one all-devouring gaze. The restless energies of the Anglo-Saxon race are but the accumulated impulse from successive stages in civilization, which have advanced for centuries past in one unbroken chain. The world at large owes much to the play of those energies, which have not been confined within the narrow limit of their own habitation, but have overflown into almost every region of the earth. We want to direct some portion of them now from Lagos to Kano and Kooka, to Abeokuta, as the first stage in that great progress. We have no hope in the more or less educated West Africans for this work. There are, of course, exceptions, and a few brilliant ones; but, as a body, they are content with the advantages they have themselves personally reaped by the aid of British Christians and philanthropists, and have not yet obtained a spark of that holy fire which impels a man irresistibly beyond the narrow sphere of self-interest and personal enjoyments. They are at present too much engrossed by admiration of themselves to care very much about the well-being and redemption from the bonds of ignorance of others. They have been accustomed to receive benefits, to have things done for them, until they have come to look upon these as a birthright. It is thus that the enunciation of a scheme for endowing Abeokuta with a railway communication with Lagos fell flat upon their ears. They did not see that there was in the project a stream into which they could at once dip their pitchers without an effort. They fancied that we wanted them to help—not that we merely desired to open to them an honourable door of participation in an effort for the spread of Christian civilization by means of the development of material resources. But this ignorant apathy has no influence on our decisions. For the sake of the people of Abeokuta, and of peoples beyond, if not for those of Lagos, although none would be more benefited materially than they, we want a railway from Gaun to Abeokuta. We want it; and, by God\'s help, we will have it. We are not blind to the difficulties in the path we have resolved, by God\'s help, to tread. The late revelations as to the degree of moral and spiritual iniquity into which men have fallen who had been stationed in the Egba country to preach the glad tidings of salvation, have shown us that even the influence of a portion of educated West Africa must be thrown into the scale against us. A railway would soon let in light, and therefore those who "love darkness rather than light, because their deeds are evil," cannot desire a railway. They could not have continued, year after year, to receive money from British Christians to make known the precepts of our Divine Master, and occupied themselves at the same time in buying, selling, working, and breeding slaves. Their iniquity could not have been hid; the increased intercourse between the interior and Lagos consequent upon railway communication, even of the simplest kind, would have led to its being immediately revealed. We must have the railway. We should not, perhaps, have made these remarks at the present time, but that we feared that as we had not made mention of this railway in our February number, our enlightened friends, the few enlightened friends in Abeokuta—alas! how few!—might feel discouragement, and fancy we had "shaken off the dust from our feet" against the indifference of Lagos, from which scarcely one word of real appreciation and encouragement has reached us. But no. A firm resolve once formed in a Christian mind, becomes a principle of action. It is not subject to changes. Irresistible "circumstance" may for a time delay its execution, but the mind will not be slumbering over it, much less moved from it. Our convictions, our desires, our intentions, our resolves, are as they were when we first put forward our project, except that they have gained instead of having diminished in strength. Let the few enlightened Christian friends to the proposed railway in Abeokuta continue, therefore, their efforts to prepare the public mind for the great innovation, and to beget in it a desire for its coming. It may be some time before we can marshal the powers indispensable for the prosecution of such a work; but as we look to Him who giveth all strength to help us in it, we believe that Gaun and Abeokuta will, ere long, have their railway.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-03-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_03_1880#article-19', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.686, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The People of Lagos upon European Influence upon the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Looking at the question from an economist\'s point of view, commercial intercourse with foreigners enriches our country. It enables us to import those commodities for the production of which the climate and soil of foreign countries are best calculated, and to export in payment those articles for which our own situation is better adapted. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. At the same time, the manufacture of those commodities for which we have no particular facilities is decreased. Take cloth, for instance; the manufacture of cloth out here costs at least a fifth more than if imported. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist\'s point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. Then, being dependent on each other for a large amount of comfort and enjoyment, it forms a powerful principle of union, and binds the society of nations together by the common and powerful ties of mutual interest and reciprocal obligation. And, lastly, by bringing us into competition with foreigners, the division of labour is carried to its farthest extent; it stimulates our industry, and forces routine to give way to invention. Commerce is the principal medium for the propagation of Christianity. In some West African countries, Europeans are at first only admitted for commercial purposes. Up the Niger and at Bonny, for instance, persecution of converts to Christianity, especially by slave-holders, was of common occurrence; but this has been greatly modified by the interposition of the European merchants. When making treaties with native tribes, the Consuls usually stipulate for religious toleration. Again, missionaries have to avail themselves of commercial conveniences such as steamers, and also of commercial protection and aid; how would the money for missionary enterprise be forthcoming but for commerce? What is religion but an exalted form of civilization? The Bible contains as good a code for the improvement of mind and manners as any book extant.', 'last_edit_date': '1885-02-16', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_05_1885#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.711, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Spread of Christian Civilization in West Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The problem that we have set ourself to solve is the spread of Christian civilization in West Africa. To this our energies are, now, as they have been for years past, devoted. To those who have not considered the matter as we have, the idea of any rapid advancement in the solution might well seem to be Utopian. We have to deal with countries in which the dense ignorance of superstitious barbarism universally prevails—with countries in which the British people do not settle as colonists, where European mercantile houses trade, but do not leave in them any of the profits, if such there be, of their commerce, and where consequently there is little or no increase of capital that may be devoted to works of improvement. We have to deal with countries in which the action of the British Government has been hitherto simply protective, and not in any degree whatever initiative; ameliorating the condition of the people only in so far as the amelioration is necessary to give protection to trade and commerce at the stations which it occupies, and in the dependent territories, by prohibiting at and within them the outrages to humanity in which the most blood-thirsty superstition known in the world formerly indulged—in abolishing that fruitful source of evil and degradation, domestic slavery, and thus leaving the field open for the civilizing agency of commercial intercourse, the unselfish efforts of philanthropy, and of those religious societies which devote themselves to the promulgation of the glad tidings of salvation among the heathen, diffusing among them the great blessing of education, and enabling them to read those Scriptures of truth on the observance of the sacred precepts contained in which the true happiness of the human race so entirely depends. Great indeed have been and are the advantages thus bestowed upon a portion of the people of West Africa. History necessarily affords no parallel. Ere yet the efforts of the British Government to put an end to the odious foreign slave-trade had been crowned with full success, the application of steam in navigation brought those countries into easy communication with the Christian civilization of Great Britain, which may be said to have swooped down upon them, embracing many of them, educated by the religious societies, in its folds. The easy access to England thus afforded by steam has been largely, and is increasingly, availed of by those who had been thus educated, and who, by trade and commerce introduced among them, have obtained the necessary pecuniary means. Not a few of the children of these have also been sent to Great Britain for education. The civilization of Europe has thus become familiar to many, while still the great masses of the people in and beyond the narrow limits of a few Coast towns remain in the dense darkness of heathen ignorance, and more or less openly the victims of heathen superstitions, without any incentive to industrial action beyond what is necessary for obtaining the commonest necessaries of life. Now those countries in which the peoples are thus left to the natural inertia of ignorant tropical humanity, must,—that is our problem—must be brought within the area of Christian civilization. We say Christian civilization, because there is a species of Mahometan civilization, as in Persia; and of heathen, as in China; neither of which we desire for Africa. How are they to be so brought? How? They cannot be so brought except by the civilization by which, we desire them to be embraced,—advancing to their help, seeking them, searching them out, holding forth to them the hand of fellowship, showing them the material advantages it enjoys, and of which it desires to make them partakers. Year after year have we brooded over this problem, our only consolation meanwhile being that the number of more or less educated natives in the Coast towns was in constant increase; that the education they were receiving, being under missionary superintendence, included some knowledge of the articles of universal Christian belief, and, at least, a theoretical acquaintance with those blessed precepts, even the very imperfect observance of which by the inhabitants of the Christian world has contributed so largely to human happiness by emancipating mankind from the cruel tyranny of evil and bringing them partially into the delicious freedom of righteousness. Those natives, more or less educated, more or less under the influence of Christian faith, more or less imbued with Christian principles, more or less governed by Christian precepts, were indispensable as a vanguard of the great army of civilization that must be projected upon the ignorant barbarism of heathen Africa whenever the means for such projection should be arranged. That they are not themselves sufficiently under the dominion of Christian civilization to lead them to become its apostles among their hitherto less favoured countrymen has been sufficiently proved by the reception accorded by some of them in Abeokuta to the proposal made by us to link that town with Lagos by means of a railway. They would none of it. They strove to set the heathen mind against it. They would rather things should remain as they are. The education they have received has only served to develop selfishness in them, by showing them the advantages they possess through it over the heathen among whom they dwell—advantages which they do not wish to see reduced by the introduction of others into that portico of the temple of knowledge in which they have themselves secured a footing. But though their help will be unwillingly given, they will and must nevertheless become an important, as they do also constitute a necessary, element in that onward march of civilization which we have projected. The more and more we have studied the problem, the more and more convinced we become, and are, that the onward march must be by means of railways between British sea-coast possessions and the interior. No half measures will suffice. As a first step toward the working out of our problem, we put forward, some twelve months and more ago, our proposals to construct four light railways: three within the Gold Coast territories proper, and one within native territory, with a British Gold Coast Colony possession as a base. We felt that the publication of these proposals would enable us to test the degree in which the educated African element might be made co-operative in the elucidation. We soon discovered that, with two or three individual exceptions, that element was nowhere sufficiently enlightened to be co-operative in any other way than by its paid employment, whenever we should be ready with the pounds, shillings, and pence with which to make the work a personal benefit to each and all of them. Our proposals did not provoke or awake or create the smallest scintilla of interest or enthusiasm. They fell flat upon the understandings, and did not quicken the pulsations of any heart. Almost every individual fraction of this element seemed to fancy that in some way or other a railway, if introduced, would interfere with or prejudice the little trading or other game in which he was engaged; and, as we have before said, with one or two exceptions, the great broad view of human misery to be relieved, of human happiness to be increased, of human emancipation from the fetters of degrading and debasing evil to be achieved, of human benefits to be bestowed, and of the spread of the knowledge of the great and precious gift of eternal life obtainable through faith in Christ Jesus, never presented itself to mind, or heart, or soul,—engrossed only by its own little personal dust-heap, in which it might be grubbing for its own little personal enjoyments, and the gratification of its own little personal vanities and desires. This discovery, for which we were fully prepared, confirmed our views that Africa can do nothing for herself, and that every...\n**67**', 'last_edit_date': '1880-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1880#article-12', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.698, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}]

hh: European interactions with African societies were characterized by complex negotiations and alliances with local leaders, facilitating safe passage and highlighting intricate relationships between different African kingdoms and European powers.
result: The observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles collectively support the claim that European interactions with African societies were characterized by complex negotiations and alliances with local leaders, facilitating safe passage and highlighting intricate relationships between different African kingdoms and European powers. The textbook details how European influence in Africa was often acquired through treaties with African rulers, involving negotiations for protection or political advantages. African leaders strategically entered these treaties to gain prestige or renounce allegiance to rival states, with missionaries and traders playing key roles in establishing mutually beneficial relationships. The text also notes alliances, such as the Baganda aligning with the British against the Banyoro, while acknowledging the divisive European strategies like "divide and conquer." Similarly, The African Times articles describe successful negotiations, such as Mr. E. Geslinger's arrangements with chiefs near Boom Falls for the safe passage of the French traveler M. Gerard, and the Great Peace Meeting in Sierra Leone, where British officials facilitated a treaty between warring tribes. The suggestion to station a consular agent in Kumasi to foster relations with Ashantee further underscores the intricate relationships. However, the articles also highlight European impositions, such as the deposition of King Ja Ja of Opobo by the British, complicating the narrative of mutual alliances. Together, these sources illustrate both cooperative and coercive interactions, emphasizing the multifaceted nature of European-African relations during this period.

[{'document_title': 'European partition and conquest of Africa: an overview', 'section_title': 'Treaty-making 1885-1902', 'content': 'Prior to the Berlin Act, European powers had acquired spheres of influence in Africa in a variety of ways - through settlement, exploration, the establishment of commercial posts, missionary settlements, the occupation of strategic areas, and by making treaties with African rulers.$^{41}$ Following the conference, influence by means of treaty became the most important method of effecting the paper partition of the continent. These treaties took two forms - those between Africans and Europeans, and bilateral agreements between the Europeans themselves. The African-European treaties were basically of two kinds. Firstly, there were the slave trade and the commercial treaties; these had generated friction, which in turn led to European political interference in African affairs. Secondly, there were the political treaties by which African rulers either purportedly surrendered sovereignty in return for protection, or undertook not to enter into treaty obligations with other European nations.
These political treaties were in vogue during our period. They were made either by representatives of European governments or by those of private organizations who later transferred them to their respective govern› ments. If a metropolitan government accepted them, the territories in question were usually annexed or declared a protectorate; if, on the other hand, it suspected their authenticity, or if it felt constrained by the vicissi› tudes of Weltpolitik to exercise caution, these treaties were used for bargaining purposes during the bilateral European negotiations. Africans, on the other hand, entered into these arrangements for a variety of motives, but particularly because of the interests of their people. In some cases, they desired treaty relations with Europeans because they hoped that the prestige of such a relationship would endow them with certain political advantages in dealing with their neighbours. Sometimes a weak African state would desire a treaty with a European power in the hope of using it to renounce allegiance to another African state that claimed sovereignty over it. European powers could afford to spend millions of pounds on overseas campaigns, African states were unable to sustain any protracted military confrontation against them.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.683, 'probability_score': 0.051, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African diaspora', 'section_title': 'The diaspora in Europe', 'content': 'Although the African diaspora took place mainly through the slave trade, Africans also found their way into the outer world as free people inde› pendent of the slave trade, or as a new phase of life after a period of slavery in the tropical Americas. Indeed, Africans had been present in Western Europe from Classical Antiquity onwards, though the numbers only became substantial from about the fifteenth century on, when black Africans, first as slaves and then as freedmen, began to appear in southern Spain and Portugal, arriving at first by way of the trans-Saharan trade to North Africa.
