[{'document_title': 'THOMAS CLARKSON.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The following brief announcement was lately made in the daily papers: "The first stone of a handsome memorial, to be erected in Wisbech, in honour of Thomas Clarkson, the advocate of negro emancipation, was laid yesterday. This earnest opponent of slavery was born in that town in 1760. The memorial will chiefly consist of a statue, designed by the late Sir Gilbert Scott, R.A." Thomas Clarkson! What a host of cherished recollections of the persevering and active devotion of this great champion of the negro slave crowd around us at the mere mention of his name, who first established, after a long and costly struggle before the British tribunals, the absolute and unconditional freedom of every negro slave so soon as his foot touched any portion of the sacred free soil within the four seas of Britain. This was the foundation-stone of the great arch of slave emancipation in British Colonies and of the entire abolition of the African foreign slave-trade, so far as concerns all but Mohammedan States, by whose demand for negro slaves all that now remains of it is kept alive. Suffolk has so much reason to be proud of this great champion of freedom that we are only surprised that so many years have been allowed to roll away before Wisbech could boast of a memorial in his honour. But his memory has lived, and will ever live, in the hearts of those who have sympathised with his efforts, and the efforts of his fellow champions, Buxton and Wilberforce. The time will, no doubt, come when regenerated Africa will do honour to those renowned champions of her long downtrodden races, who, under the instigation of the demon of greed, were made to prey upon each other, and deluge the whole land in blood, for the benefit of the accursed foreign slave-dealer and his employers and patrons. The light is slowly penetrating the dense atmosphere of African barbarism. O that the dawn would indeed come! There are fringes of something like light on some portions of the horizon which give hope of that coming dawn; but the change from darkness to light seems to us very slow; yet would Clarkson, Wilberforce, and Buxton rejoice to see what we now behold, imperfect and feeble though the advance seems to us to be—Negro doctors, negro barristers, members of the London College of Surgeons, and of the Inns of Court; negro editors of newspapers and almanacks, negro merchants and traders, negro catechists and schoolmasters, and over and above all a negro bishop and archdeacon, with many negro pastors and teachers. No, Clarkson, Buxton, Wilberforce, and others did not strive, have not laboured in vain, and there will be some day a glorious springing up of the dry bones to flesh and life.', 'last_edit_date': '1880-11-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_11_1880#article-15', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.675, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE STANLEY & AFRICAN EXHIBITION IN LONDON.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'its proper dimensions on a modern map, on which the "Empire of Monomotapa" is shrunk up into a little corner between the Zambesi and one of its southern tributaries.

In the centre of the floor of the lower gallery is a fine bust of Mr. Stanley, and the original cast of the African group of the Albert Memorial. Behind is a fine specimen of one of Mr. Du Chaillu's gorillas. The main exhibits in the lower gallery are arranged geographically in the numerous panels around the walls. On one side spears are the most conspicuous objects, and the variety of type is quite striking. We have spears from Somaliland, the Masai country, the Congo, Uganda, Swaziland, the Nyassa region, the Tanganyika region. Nearly all of these spears, as well as the other exhibits, have been collected by explorers whose names are famous, men like Livingstone, Speke and Grant, Stanley and Thomson, Johnston, and many missionaries; the officials of the Congo Free State, and others. Very varied are the types of axes, many of them of elaborate form. Bows and arrows are not numerous; but shields are plentiful and varied, and it is of interest to note that the Zulu shield extends to the latitude of Zanzibar, where we find a tribe long settled there, and yet retain many of the old Zulu customs. Some of the personal ornaments are most extraordinary. There are anklets like enormous brass plates, with a hole through the centre; others made of bars of copper, each over a pound weight. Then some of the "money" is of a strange character. The utensils of metal and pottery are as varied as the weapons. One exhibit which will no doubt interest many visitors is the complete equipment for a horse brought by Mr. Thomson from Sokoto.

Some of the objects in the glass cases will probably prove among the most attractive exhibits. There are Livingstone's Consular cap and sword, and his simple knife and fork and sugar basin. One of Gordon's famous Khartoum notes, lent by Sir H. Peek, has a strange interest, so also has a page from Bishop Hannington's original diary, and one of the flags of his expedition, with the word "Ichabod" upon it. Some specimens of the Ashanti gold ornaments are sure to attract attention.

What will interest a large section of the public is the abundance of exhibits in the gallery illustrative of missionary effort and the slave trade. Here we have many famous missionary portraits from Krapf and Moffat downwards, with specimens of the Scriptures in many native languages. Sir Fowell Buxton has lent his great picture of the "Middle Passage" by Biard; and there are portraits of his father, of Wilberforce, and many other pioneers of abolition.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-04-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1890#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.687, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'SURGEONS FOR THE WEST COAST OF AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Sir,—I am sure you will insert a few words on a subject of great importance with us, and allow me to commence by asking, Who in Jamaica are your learned men of the law? Who are your most successful physicians and surgeons? Who are your wise legislators? Who occupy seats as chiefs on the bench of our high courts of judicature? Who are our most prosperous men of business out of England? I answer, *the black man!* and I know there are no white men with an honest conscience who have lived in the West Indies that will contradict it. Then, why should these men, whom God created and called man, be denied positions as medical men in Africa? Because they are black, is the reply of Captain Brownwell, of the late distinguished Gold Coast Artillery Corps, and Mr. Charles O'Callaghan, the surgeon attached to the said late corps. I should like to know if Captain Brownwell and Mr. O'Callaghan represent Western Africa? I say that it is most unaccountable audacity on the part of these two officers to put forth a statement of this kind, involving as it does so mighty a question of Africa's capability to rise in the human scale from civilised nations, and govern herself at some future day. We hope that Christian England will not allow this untrue, unauthorised, and unwarrantable statement to influence her against her good wishes to unfortunate Africa. I say that the African is capable of all the attainments that belong to the white man; and in spite of Messrs. Brownwell and O'Callaghan, Africa and the Africans will and must rise from their long degradation. God in His mercy hasten that day. If Messrs.

[January 23, 1864.

Brownwell and O'Callaghan's statement were taken for value, good-bye to our schools, and all attempts to civilise Africa. Clarkson, Buxton, Brougham, Wilberforce, and a host of other great men's convictions, must be treated as absurd fancies, if we allow this base imputation to go unanswered or unresented.', 'last_edit_date': '1864-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1864#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Roll of African Worthies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Our heart swells with exultation whenever we are able to point to a name to be inscribed on the historical roll of African worthies. We have still among us in Great Britain not a few who contemptuously deny the common brotherhood of the African and the European; who determinedly ignore the effects of degrading influences through a long succession of generations on the one, and the effects of ennobling influences throughout a similar period on the other; and, comparing the actual condition of the two, bidding us "look on this picture and on this," maintain that they are not the "counterfeit presentment of two brothers," of two divisions of the great human family derived originally from one common stock, but of two races essentially different, the one inherently and ineradicably lower than the other in the scale of intellectual being. It is therefore not surprising that we, who contend for the Scriptural truth of the common humanity of all men and peoples on the face of this earth, should feel our heart bound with joy when one of those whom our spoiled children of science, and the inheritors of slave-trade prejudices, would relegate to the lower place, vindicates by deeds which, in European estimation, are regarded as ennobling to humanity the claim of his race to an equality with the proud "Caucasian." Such a man was Doctor Davis, of whose lamented death while engaged in a voluntary, self-imposed, gratuitous, and most self-denying work among the wretched victims of a cruel war, a notice will this month be found in our columns. When we reflect that it is only five-and-thirty years since the debasing chain of slavery was removed from those of the African race in Barbadoes, and that this man, born within ten years after, should have thus wrung from French, Germans, and Englishmen such high and well-deserved tributes of loving gratitude, admiration, and praise, we experience a fresh stimulus to exertion for Africans in Africa to effect, as soon as possible, that every impediment to their progress in Christian civilisation may be removed, that every badge of their supposed inferiority shall be obliterated, and that institutions shall be planted among them calculated to foster and develop that worthy spirit of emulation to rival their European brethren which we regard as a powerful spring of action in the coming regeneration of Africa; and it does seem to us that both Sierra Leone and Lagos, which are the, at present, chief points of civilised commercial development on the West Coast, ought to lose no time in erecting in Sierra Leone and in Lagos a column on which shall be from time to time inscribed the names of those of the African race in whose favour the world may pronounce, as in the case of the late lamented Dr. Davis; and of others whose future services to Africa, in Africa and elsewhere, may, by universal acclaim among them, be deemed worthy to be had in undying remembrance, as worthy of honour and imitation by their brother Africans.', 'last_edit_date': '1870-12-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_12_1870#article-16', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.71, 'probability_score': 0.068, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE LATE DR. HORTON', 'section_title': '', 'content': "In our last month's number we recorded the nomination of Dr. Horton as a Prince of Ashanti; and now, alas! it is our melancholy task to register his decease. Although he had been greatly suffering during his visit to England last year, we had cherished the hope that his restoration to health had been perfect, and that many years of honourable usefulness were still before him. We give in another column an extract from the Christian Observer, of Sierra Leone, which will give some slight idea of the high estimation in which he was held in his native city. He fully merited that esteem. As a sincere and attached friend of many years, we deeply deplore his loss. No man has more successfully vindicated the just claim of the African race to mental equality with the more favoured portions of mankind. The son of liberated Africans—that is, of Africans who had been rescued from on board slave-ships by cruisers of Her Majesty's Navy—he had the disadvantage of being of the first generation of his family in the ranks of civilization. He had none of the advantages possessed by Europeans of hereditary culture. What he effected was all his own—all the fruit of his own labour, utilizing the elements placed at his disposal by the Christian philanthropy of Great Britain. The Church Missionary Society may record his name with pride as among the fruit of their persistent labours in West Africa; and Her Majesty's Government had certainly no cause to regret having taken him into the medical ranks of the Army, in which he attained to the high position of Surgeon-Major, and from which he retired last year, after a full period of service, but without receiving the decoration of St. Michael and St. George, which could only have been withheld because he was an African. It is scarcely necessary to say that we deeply sympathize with his bereaved family.", 'last_edit_date': '1883-12-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_12_1883#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.672, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE ACTION OF THE AFRICAN-AID SOCIETY.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Africa, anything beyond the mere egotism of surface philanthropy, it will find fresh support. If it ever perish for want of it, while, as now, faithful in its mission, disgrace to those who shall have allowed it to perish. And here we must say one word to the educated Africans of the West Coast. They have recognised, and are recognising, by their subscriptions to this paper, the importance to them of the African Times. But they have not as yet done anything for the support of The Society whose influence makes that journal a power. In future every subscription will be published in this paper. Every educated and commercial African ought to feel that this society is his. The name of every one ought to be found year by year in the list of its annual subscribers. There are hundreds who can afford their one or two guineas a-year. It is only thus they can show that they recognise the important efforts of this society for them and for their race and country; thus only they can show that they are alive to the vast benefits of the civilization of which they have themselves become partakers. It was for this that we hailed with peculiar satisfaction the annual subscription of the Rev. Mr. Robbin, Colonial Chaplain at the Gambia, as announced in our last. His worthy and honoured name stands first on the list of our African subscribers. We hope, for the credit of the educated Africans, that it is but the first of hundreds. Then will the people of England recognise the advancing civilization of Africa.', 'last_edit_date': '1863-05-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_05_1863#article-9', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.68, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'BRITISH MISRULE IN WEST AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Under this heading there has lately appeared in the London Daily Graphic a series of illustrated articles, tending to show how demoralizing to the Native mind is much that arises from the present system of British rule and influence in this part of the world. It is now more than a century since Sierra Leone was founded, to be a centre of light and civilisation for the whole West Coast of Africa; and it must be admitted by every one who has made a study of this matter, that so far this purpose has not been achieved. When we look to India and Australia we are struck with wonder at the marvellous material and moral progress which is the outcome of a century of British rule. But with Africa—the West Coast especially—the result is far different; in spite of the great extension of European influence in that portion of the world, it is doubtful whether the Native, quâ Native, is really the better for what has been brought before him during the last hundred years. Not that it is his fault; at least, entirely. When Great Britain set herself to the task of redeeming the great debt which she, above all nations, owed to Africa—for was not she the originator of the shameful Slave Trade?—she was prompted doubtless by the best of motives, but did not fully appreciate the difficulties of the task she then undertook. To repair the wrong she herself had inflicted there was but one sure course—to devote her best. The history of the past century is one long catalogue of failures in this respect, and the result is made manifest now, when we see the Native West African brought down by the drink traffic to a level lower than that of those who have not been affected by the so-called civilisation.

Speaking of the demoralizing effect of the unchecked drink traffic, Mr. F. Buxton, in the Daily Graphic, draws a sharp contrast between the present moral and social state of the Natives in the French colony of the Gaboon and what he saw at Freetown. "Freetown, with its hills rising behind it, forms a pretty picture from the bay where ships lie at anchor, but the town itself is fairer to behold from a distance than pleasant to inspect closely. Landing in this English settlement I was', 'last_edit_date': '1891-03-02', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/02_03_1891#article-7', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'CAPTAIN CAMERON, R.N., ON AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the meeting of the Balloon Society, on July 18, a lecture was delivered by Captain V. Lovett Cameron, R.N., on "Africa."

The lecturer said that the further British influence extended in Africa the more would slavery of every kind be done away with. Besides illegal slavery, there was extensively practised in Africa a system of native despotism which it was very desirable should be abolished. In 1876 nobody seemed to take any notice of Africa, and the exportation of India-rubber from Zanzibar amounted to something under £20,000. Now the amount was about £250,000! With respect to ill-health in that continent, he had found that some of the native treatments were by no means to be despised, and many of our English doctors could take a leaf out of their book. The record of men who had travelled through Africa and endured every conceivable kind of hardship proved that Africa had been cursed by the idea of its unhealthiness, a reproach which it did not deserve. The great thing required, however, was adequate communication. African travelling, under present circumstances, meant, at the outside, fifty miles in a week. At the present time every mile of railroad laid down in Africa drove a dozen nails into the coffin of the slave-trade, to say nothing of the immense impetus to trade and commerce which would thus be afforded. From Cairo right away to the Albert Nyanza was navigable water. There would be no difficulty in overcoming the obstacles of cataracts, &c., which modern engineering would easily surmount. The central high plateau of Africa was, to a great extent, in British hands, and offered the most important means of repressing the slave-trade in future. Every slave working at the present time was in direct defiance of the Act of 1873. Mr. Rhodes' great railway, which would reach Zambesia within eight years, should be kept under British control, as native treaties were more or less uncertain. In 1876 they could have obtained all that is now German territory by holding up their hands. The Germans, however, are practically locked in. A dispute had been going on with Portugal as to whether the Zambesi was an open highway. Fortunately, owing to the twenty-one miles strip of land granted by England to Germany these two powers would be as one on the question, and in future arbitration claim the Zambesi as an open highway. A wise system of emigration should be conducted. He would like to see Indian planters transferred there, and Chinese too. Africa offered an excellent opening for the English working man, and it was desirable that the Government should protect its emigrants. The dangers of Africa were largely dwelt on nowadays, and its advantages were put in the rear. This was the reason why the development of that great continent was so far behind hand.

The following resolution was proposed by Admiral Field, M.P., seconded by Mr. Johnson (of the Stanley Falls, Congo):—', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-18', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1890#article-1', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.682, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'To Lord Alfred Churchill President, and the Members of the African-Aid Society', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'There can be no better proof that education and trade are making way on the West Coast of Africa than is furnished by the Report of the Postmaster-General for 1864. The letters between Great Britain and West Africa, which in 1857 numbered only 51,000, amounted during the year 1863 to 103,000—an annual increase of 52,000, or above 100 per cent., in no more than seven years.

The late lamented Dr. Baikie died, not of fever and dysentery, but of Guinea worm. We shall give some account of this in our next.

The Abeokuta paper says: "Notice of confirmation by the Lord Bishop of Sierra Leone has been given in the various churches of Abeokuta. A large number of persons have come forward as candidates for that holy rite. The Bishop is expected to arrive at Lagos by the coming mail steamer." We are sorry to see this. We had hoped that since the consecration of Bishop

Crowther, such a perilous journey on the part of the Bishop of Sierra Leone, whose health is far from good, would be unnecessary.', 'last_edit_date': '1865-01-23', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_01_1865#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'AFRICA AT THE MEETING OF THE BRITISH ASSOCIATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'At the meeting of the British Association, held this year at Newcastle-on-Tyne, the things of Africa came in for a good deal of discussion and consideration.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1889#article-5', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.677, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Commercial Value of Africa', 'section_title': '', 'content': '"Altogether our West African possessions do a trade with Great Britain (mainly with Liverpool, London, and Bristol) of about £5,000,000 yearly, give honourable employment to some 770 of our British fellow-countrymen, and bring at least 5,000,000 of intelligent (Sierra Leone), sturdy (Krumen), industrious (Gold Coast), artistic (Yoruba), brave (Niger), good-tempered (Oil Rivers) negroes under our sway. I have dwelt more in detail on the extent of our interests in West Africa than on those which we possess in other parts of the Continent, because it is with West Africa that the inhabitants and commerce of the United Kingdom are most concerned. I mean that the trade of our West African possessions, and the employment given to British subjects, are directed almost solely to Great Britain. If we gave away the Gold Coasts or Lagos, or the Niger, for instance, in exchange for concessions from France or Germany in the Pacific or the North Atlantic, the ratio of loss to the inhabitants of Great Britain would be far greater than the gain to the Australians or the Newfoundlanders. To those who argue that our missionaries and merchants might go on working in West Africa just the same, even if the rule in our possession were transferred to another Power, I would ask, 'How many British merchants are there in French Senegambia? What is the total of British trade with the French, German, Belgian, Portuguese possessions in West Africa as compared to that carried on with the districts under the British flag? Are the British missionaries able to conduct their evangelisation in French Africa? In the most enlightened and liberal-minded of these foreign administrations, the German possession of Cameroons, did not the English Baptist Mission, who had laboured there for forty years prior to the German advent, have to leave the country after the German rule was established?' We should not blame the Governments of foreign powers for these results. The fault lies in our peculiar idiosyncrasies as a people. We are of a cranky, self-willed, unaccommodating disposition, tolerably patient under the government of our own fellow-countrymen, but utterly impatient of foreign control. While, however, our possessions of Western Africa are become a necessity to the trade of Liverpool, Manchester, Burnley, Birmingham, Leeds, Sheffield, Bristol, and London, our newly-gained spheres of influence in South Central Africa—besides the important Scotch interests which they concern—are a necessity for the commercial expansion and feeding-ground of our growing British South African Confederation, which has a total population of over 2,000,000, and does a yearly trade with the United Kingdom of £18,000,000 in value. Then as to Zanzibar and British East Africa, they, in their turn, besides securing the southern approach to the dominions of our Egyptian ward, are a necessity to the trade and overflow emigration of our great Indian Empire, with its nearly 300,000,000 of people and its yearly trade with the British Empire of some £90,000,000. The trade of the British Empire with British Africa amounts to about £25,200,000 yearly. Among the more valuable products which British Africa sends us, or supplies to herself, may be cited the following: gold, silver, copper, coal, diamonds, ivory, rubber, palm oil, palm kernels, gums, cotton, dyewoods, indigo, coffee, sugar, rice, Indian corn, horses, cattle, donkeys, hides, amomum seeds, red peppers, and many other valuable dyes, spices, oils, timber, drugs, skins, and farinaceous foods.', 'last_edit_date': '1890-09-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.674, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}]

hh: The interactions between African leaders and European powers during the colonial period were marked by complex alliances, rivalries, and both collaboration and resistance.
result: The interactions between African leaders and European powers during the colonial period were marked by complex alliances, rivalries, and both collaboration and resistance, as evidenced by observations from both the "General History of Africa" textbook and The African Times news articles. The textbook highlights how African rivalries facilitated European strategies of divide and rule, with some African groups aiding colonial powers to settle scores with their neighbors. It discusses leaders like Tippu Tib and the sons of Msiri, who allied with Europeans to fulfill expansionist goals and strengthen their internal positions, while refuting the simplistic classification of African leaders as mere collaborators. Instead, it portrays a nuanced picture of African responses, ranging from armed resistance to strategic alliances, emphasizing the diverse motivations behind these actions. Similarly, The African Times articles provide examples such as Lieutenant Mage's expedition in Senegal, where alliances were formed with local chiefs like Samba Niadje-Sarrakolet, illustrating collaboration and strategic alliances. The French occupation of Baddiboo in Gambia, leading to tensions with the British, exemplifies the rivalries and breaches of neutrality in European colonial ambitions. Resistance is also highlighted, as seen in the Cameroons with trade boycotts following German bombardment, and in Buganda, where Arab traders incited resistance against Christian missionaries. The Niger Company's mission to Bornou further underscores local leaders' reluctance to engage with Western influences. Together, these sources underscore the multifaceted nature of African-European relations during the colonial era, characterized by a blend of cooperation, resistance, and strategic maneuvering.

Ultimately, changing conditions within the world capitalist economy provoked opposition to their participation in the slave trade and, together with growing European imperial ambitions, set the stage for an intensive conflict.", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.688, 'probability_score': 0.05, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'African politics and nationalism, 1919-35', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Only few of the colonial administrators seemed to have understood how to manage the uneasy relationship which existed between the 'traditional' and the new African elites on the one hand, and between these two sets of elites and the colonial regimes on the other. The few exceptions included, notably, General (later Marshal) Lyautey in Morocco, Sir Frederick (later Lord) Lugard in Northern Nigeria and Sir Gordon Guggisberg in the Gold Coast (now Ghana). Even for these, the general strategy consisted in dampening the aspirations of the new educated elite who were usually portrayed as ambitious upstarts. In such a situation neither set of elites was satisfied with the colonial regimes. In 1917, Governor-General Joost Van Vollenhoven highlighted the potentially explosive nature of the problem, especially in relation to the future of colonialism, in the following perceptive piece: The indigenous chiefs, those of yesterday whom we have preserved, or those of today whom we have created, complain of being humiliated. The 'interpreters', the various types of auxiliaries of the administration and of commerce, complain that they are 'instruments' and do not have the rank due to them as collaborators. There is among the whole of this badly payed and very wretched elite - as remote from indigenous society, from which it has been driven out, as it is from European society into which it is not admitted - a feeling of disillusionment, discontent and bitterness which it would prove dangerous to be unaware of. 3", 'last_edit_date': None, 'url': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.679, 'probability_score': 0.049, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'European partition and conquest of Africa: an overview', 'section_title': 'The partition of Africa and the new imperialism: a review > The beginnings of the Scramble', 'content': "Although by the end of the third quarter of the nineteenth century, the European powers of France, Britain, Portugal and Germany had acquired commercial interests and were exercising considerable influence in different parts of Africa, their direct political control there was extremely limited. The first was the new interest which the Duke of Brabant, crowned a constitutional king (Leopold I) of the Belgians in 1865, proclaimed in Africa. This was signified by the so-called Brussels Geographical Conference which he convened in 1876 and which resulted in the setting up of the African International Association and the employment of H. M. Stanley in 1879 to explore the Congos in the name of the Association. [{'id': 459, 'article_title': 'FRENCH EXPLORATION OF THE RIVER NIGER.', 'full_section_title': 'FRENCH EXPLORATION OF THE RIVER NIGER.', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/23_09_1864#article-23', 'issue_date': '23_09_1864', 'content': "Letters from Senegal, dated 5th July, give an account of an expedition at present engaged in exploring the course of the Niger, under the auspices of the French Government. The plan of the expedition was drawn up by General Faidherbe, Governor of Senegal, and its execution confided by him to Lieutenant Mage, of the Imperial Navy, and M. Quentin, a naval surgeon. The object of the explorers is to trace the lower course of the river from the kingdom of Timbuctoo to the Atlantic, of which scarcely anything is known. There is, however, good reason to believe that it passes through regions rich in natural products, which would offer great resources to trade and industry. General Faidherbe is anxious to open communications between these countries and the French possessions in that part of Africa, and this is the principal object of the enterprise undertaken by Lieutenant Mage, who is well known for his previous explorations in 1859 and 1860. The last letters received from the travellers, dated 2nd May, state that the expedition had descended the Niger from Nyamina to Segou, and were then staying at the latter place with an influential chief named Samba Niadje-Sarrakolet, who had passed a considerable time in Senegal, and there acquired from the French some knowledge of the military art. He is at present an officer of engineers in the service of El-Hadj-Omar, one of the most powerful sovereigns of Central Africa, and has built fortresses for that prince at Segou, Sikoro, Koundain, and Niora. The explorers were in hopes of soon being able to continue their journey, after first going to Haindallahi to pay a visit to El-Hadj-Omar, who appears disposed to enter into friendly relations with France. They have forwarded to Governor Faidherbe much interesting information respecting the countries through which they have passed. The populations are everywhere in a state of continual hostility, but their chiefs seem inclined to form alliances with France. Should these alliances be realised, a political situation similar to that which exists in Upper Senegal would soon follow, and posts and establishments would be founded by which the Niger would be placed in communication with Senegal. The letters from which the above particulars are extracted represent the situation of Senegal as most satisfactory. Tranquillity had been perfectly restored in the Cayor; the works at the establishment at N'guigus were terminated, and Madiolou, the chief appointed by the French, was conducting the Government undisturbed, by his late adversary, Lat Dior, who had been abandoned by all his partisans. — *Galignani.*"}, {'id': 5546, 'article_title': 'THE GAMBIA.', 'full_section_title': 'THE GAMBIA.', 'last_edit_date': '05-24-1887', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1887#article-5', 'issue_date': '01_06_1887', 'content': 'The following important telegram from Gambia has just been received in Manchester on May 24: "Bathurst River, Gambia. The French flag is hoisted at Baddiboo, on the banks of the British river Gambia."

Private telegrams from the Gambia take a serious view of the action of the French Government of Senegal in occupying Baddiboo. It is reported that the Governor-in-Chief of Senegal was present with the French troops in the collision with Said Mattei. Although the territory of this chief of Baddiboo is not actually British, it being on the borders of the Gambia, and he being subsidized by the British Government, any occupation of his country by the French troops constitutes a breach of neutrality. There is considerable alarm among the British residents, but fortunately Sir Samuel Rowe, Governor-in-Chief of the West African Settlements, had just arrived from England, and was taking prompt steps to protect British interests. Trade in Gambia is much disturbed; the ground nut crop there this season will not exceed 4,000 tons, or one-fifth of the usual crop, owing principally to internal disturbances, and there will be a very serious decline in the revenue. Later telegrams have been received to the effect that Said Mattei, King of Baddiboo, picked a quarrel with and attacked the King of the Saloum country, which is a few miles north of the Gambia and under the protectorate of the French Government. The Governor of Senegal immediately went to the assistance of the King of Saloum with a regiment of Spahis and a battalion of Marine Infantry, and drove Said Mattei out of his own country.

As mentioned above, Sir Samuel Rowe has arrived at Bathurst. He has been despatched by the Colonial Office to inquire into the depressed state of trade on the Gambia, and to report on the political aspect of affairs generally in the settlement. The Hon. Gilbert Carter, the acting Administrator, has been detained for a short time, so that Governor Rowe might have the benefit of his local knowledge and advice in the present complicated condition of Gambia affairs.'}, {'id': 6301, 'article_title': 'THE CONGO FREE STATE', 'full_section_title': 'THE CONGO FREE STATE', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1893#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_02_1893', 'content': "Important news was received from the Congo early in January. Lieut. Dhanis, in command of the camp of Lusambo, which is intended to protect the south-west territories of the Free State against the incursions of the Arabs of Manyema, has started upon an expedition against the latter. Moharra, the rival of Tippoo Tib and ally of Rumaliza of Ujiji, after denying the agents of the Company of the Upper Congo access to the countries over which he rules, ordered the massacre of Hodister and his companions between Bena Kamba and Kiba Riba. Lieut. Dhanis, after having established and fortified advanced posts on the Lomani above Bena Kamba, has now declared war upon him. The Belgian force is very much smaller than Moharra's, but Lieut. Dhanis's position is well protected. Sefu, the son of Tippoo Tib, who commands the Arabs at Nyangwe, accompanied by the Belgian resident at his Court, has joined M. Dhanis and will march with him against Moharra. Another Arab chief, Kibonze, who has a kind of vendetta against Moharra, is also preparing to attack him.

While the Free State thus repels from the west to the east towards Tanganyika and from the south to the north towards the Nile the Arab slave and ivory hunters, who resist the putting down of the slave trade, the Anti-Slavery Society of Brussels is taking steps to organise the reinforcements to protect the station it has founded on the western shore of Lake Tanganyika. Captain Jacques, who is in a perilous situation at Albertville on the mouth of the Lukunga, near the slave tract, will have the supplies of cannon, arms, and ammunition, and the men he has asked for. The subscription has already reached £3,000. Three Belgian officers will command the reinforcements. Instead of taking the Zanzibar route through Tabora, they will go by the Zambesi and the Shire.

The Free State and the French Government have at length agreed on the frontier line—namely, the Moomu and its tributary, the Schinko, which comes from the Bahr-el-Gazal territory and falls into the Mbomu near Bangasso. After protracted negotiations between the Comte de Grelle Rogier and M. Ribot, this was offered as a last concession by France, and King Leopold has agreed to it.

The officer in command of the camp of Basoko has prohibited access to the Lomani by the Congo in the case of vessels attempting to ascend the river towards Bena Kamba, as the Arabs have threatened to exterminate all Europeans who venture on their territory.

The Arabs of the Falls have thus far committed no act of aggression against the authorities of the Congo State, but seem to have adopted an arrogant attitude, which obliges the latter to stand upon the defensive."}]

[{'document_title': 'The Extension of our West African Colonies', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'They have not arrived at either of these conclusions without solid grounds. While French and German expeditions were being organised on either side, the Niger Company last winter despatched an embassy to the Sultan of Bornou to find out by personal negotiations what attitude he is prepared to assume towards the entire wave of European influence which is approaching his empire from the west. The expedition, about 300 strong, was under the command of the Company's officer, Mr. Charles Macintosh, who had with him a staff of two or three other Europeans; a part of his convoy consisted of the Houssa troops of the Company, and the remainder was made up of porters bearing food and equipment for the party, together with a liberal supply of presents for the monarch whom it was hoped to propitiate. The whole party were fully armed, but their instructions were to regard themselves as a strictly peaceful mission, and to take every precaution to avoid bloodshed. As the country between the Benue and Lake Tchad was unknown, food was taken for the whole journey. A draft treaty between the Niger Company and the Sultan of Bornou was confided to the diplomatic care of Mr. Macintosh to negotiate if possible. The party left Ribago, on the Benue, in October, and struck in a due northerly direction for Kouka. The distance as the crow flies is something less than 250 miles, not so far as from London to Durham. It was traversed at the rate of ten or twelve miles a day, and after three weeks' travelling, the expedition arrived at the Court of Bornou. Scientific observations of the country were taken on the way. The natives, from whom nothing was requested, were not otherwise than friendly. At Kouka, which is a considerable town, with a population of about 120,000, and regarded as the western terminus of Mohammedan civilisation in Central Africa, the arrival of Europeans created no small sensation. The Embassy was well received by the Sultan, who assigned it quarters in the town, and was pleased to accept as a preliminary to negotiations some portion of the presents which were offered to him. Two months of Oriental dilly-dally followed, during which time the officers of the Company made use of their opportunity to acquire political and commercial information relating to Bornou and its sister States. Arabs from all quarters thronged about them, and the Houssa language, which is the _lingua franca_ of the Central States, served as a medium of communication. Political factions abound at the Court of Kouka as elsewhere; but the result left in the minds of Mr. Macintosh and his companions after prolonged discussion with the various leaders is that all factions unite in a determination to repel the approach of Western civilisation. Bornou draws all its knowledge of the outer world from the reports of pilgrims and caravans travelling to Mecca and other centres of the East. The Mahdist disturbances in the Soudan, which have forced pilgrims to Mecca, to pass by way of Cairo, have had the effect, as regards Bornou, of keeping it better informed than it was before of the progress of the world's affairs, and have contributed to weld it and the neighbouring States more closely to the Eastern and Mohammedan as opposed to the Western and Christian system. The power and influence of Senousism in the Central States have not been, so far as the Niger Mission was able to ascertain, in any sense over-estimated by general report. Religious fanaticism supported by the sword is the prevailing spirit of government in Bornou. A well-established current of trade with the East and long-standing political traditions at present serve to combine all interests against European intrusion. It is neither England nor France nor Germany which is feared, but the European as European, the revolution of steam and enlightenment and liberty as against the camel and ignorance and despotism. The persistence of the European is well known, but while he presents himself in the peaceful guise of a trader only arms will suffice to drive him back. There is not a caravan which comes across the desert that does not bring evidence of the fact that, whether in Egypt, or Tripoli, or Turkey, the European, once admitted, reduces the Oriental to submission. The East has but one story. Bornou is of the East, and it stands in the position of a man who has never tasted wine and who sees his neighbour drunk. He realises all the consequences; he has never experienced the force of the circumstances which have produced them. The Sultan of Bornou and his advisers say in their pride, "The evil has all come from having dealings with the West. We will have no dealings with the West, unless they are imposed upon us by force of arms."', 'last_edit_date': '1891-10-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_10_1891#article-4', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The African Times.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'Two events of the past month are likely to have a lasting influence upon the future of Africa. Perhaps the most important of these is the convention or agreement between Great Britain and Germany, whereby the "sphere of influence" of these two Powers has been clearly defined in regard to territory which has been for a long time the subject of diplomatic dispute, and might have become the occasion of trouble even more serious still. This is a matter the importance of which it is almost impossible to over-estimate.

So long as any Power makes a claim which is considered to be inconsistent with the rights, or fancied rights, of another, not only is there sure to be a considerable amount of friction in the relations of those two Powers, but such a state of things is necessarily very prejudicial to the country concerned, especially when it is only just being opened out to the influences of civilisation. It is for this, among other reasons, that the agreement between Great Britain and Germany will be welcomed by all who are interested in the advance of Africa. With regard to the details of this arrangement, we find that England admits the claim of Germany to...', 'last_edit_date': '1890-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1890#article-8', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.623, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Progress on the West African Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The rivers are connected by a network of cross creeks, being indeed one delta; so from the Opobo Ja Ja's people found their way to the interior oil markets, and the oil trade of Opobo was established. The trade flourished, and Ja Ja was respected for his fair dealing and his great ability to govern his own people. Meanwhile, treaties of friendship had been made, courts of equity had been established in the various stations; regulations for trade, customs, and other subjects of interest were decided, the British Consul inspecting the proceedings from time to time. Of late years there has been a growing inclination on the part of the traders to establish themselves up the rivers at the interior oil markets, so dispensing with the services of the coast tribes. In Opobo this movement was resisted by Ja Ja, for the reason that the welfare of his people depended upon their employment as middlemen, and as no customs would be paid on the produce bought by the Europeans. He was last year accused of obstructing the Europeans from proceeding to the interior, at the time that his son was in England complaining that the Europeans were invading his markets. Ja Ja was made prisoner by Consul Johnstone, and carried off to Accra. An inquiry was held at Accra upon the charges brought against Ja Ja, and the Admiral holds that they are mainly proved; and Ja Ja is deposed, and will not be allowed to return to the Opobo river. He will, however, be allowed an annual pension of £800 for life.

The principle having been laid down that Europeans may trade in the interior, it becomes imperative to assume definite authority over the district. The "customs" have been abolished, a uniform export duty of 2s. 6d. per ton being levied instead. As things stand, we make no pretence to the sovereignty of the country; we only constitute ourselves the final authority in matters of dispute between the natives and traders of whatever nationality, and debar our continental neighbours from proclaiming themselves masters of the country. Whether things will remain as they now are is the doubtful point; pretexts for occupation are so easily found when wanted that it would be rash to answer. Some tribe is reached who cannot understand dual control; they insist on customs, perhaps; are "chastised" by the Consul; they retaliate, and finally an occupation is proclaimed. This is the danger to which we are exposed, for the destruction of the natives means loss to the traders and the abandonment of commerce. Let this be borne in mind, and we may escape the slough into which other nations have fallen.', 'last_edit_date': '1888-06-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_06_1888#article-2', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'The Political Troubles on the West Coast', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'The British and African steamer Opobo, with mails and passengers from the West Coast of Africa, arrived at Liverpool a short time since. Health on the coast was still unsatisfactory, and trade dull. At Bonny and Opobo there had been no further hostility since the British Consul had held a "palaver," and both peoples were settling down to trade. At Salt Pond trade was at a standstill, owing to fighting going on a few miles from the coast. The trouble was between the tribes in the interior, those on the sea-coast, and the natives known as the "middlemen." Both parties were desirous of direct intercourse, which the "middlemen" natives were doing all they could to prevent. The effect was that business was stopped, and several encounters had taken place. The war in the Ashantee country showed no signs of abatement.

Affairs in the Cameroons are in a very unsatisfactory state. It is said that the natives have boycotted all the whites, and refused to trade with them or supply them with food. No white man can buy a fowl or a bullock, and the natives have barred the way to the fresh water, so that the whites have to depend upon rain for all the water they require. Large numbers of the factories up the river are closed, and the traders are sending their working staffs home. The natives are determined that the German Government shall derive no advantages from the port. They are paying up all the debts they owe to the white traders, but are doing no fresh business. The people on both sides of the river have joined together, and made common cause against the Government. They do not threaten, nor will they fight, but they will not work. Their houses as well as their plantations were all destroyed when the Germans bombarded the town, so that they have nothing to lose. The English traders have had an interview with the Vice-Consul and the German Governor, and unless some compromise is effected, it will only be a question of how long the traders will keep their factories open, as they are losing money daily.', 'last_edit_date': '1886-07-01', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_07_1886#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.618, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'MR. JOSEPH THOMSON ON EUROPEAN INTERCOURSE WITH AFRICA.', 'section_title': '', 'content': "Having glanced at African exploration during the past 400 years, the lecturer proceeded to inquire what had been the net outcome of direct and indirect efforts and sacrifices and intercourse between the European and the African. He knew that the impression they had acquired from various sources was that the beneficent results were enormous; but he had been enabled to see for himself the nature of those results and to draw his own conclusions, and he appeared before them to put a pin into the beautiful iridescent bubble which they had blown for themselves with the materials supplied by the ignorant, the interested, the colour-blind, and the hopelessly biassed. Taking a bird's-eye view of the whole situation in time and space, so that each factor might assume its proper relative position and proportion, he unhesitatingly affirmed in the plainest language that so far their intercourse with African races, instead of being a blessing, had been little better than an unmitigated curse to them. These were strong statements, they would say, and required confirmation. If true, what could possibly have caused this frightful miscarriage of the noblest aspirations of a Christian people? The answer was simply the nature of their commerce with Africa in the past and present. To the slave and gin trades, and that in gunpowder and guns, must he ascribed the frightful evils they had brought upon the negro race, beside which the good they had tried to achieve was hardly discernible.", 'last_edit_date': '1890-01-11', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_02_1890#article-3', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.652, 'probability_score': 0.069, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Leader', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'all went well; "peace, quietness, and justice began to reign in the land," we are told; but soon discussions arose, the Arab traders saw that the growth of Christian influence was fatal to the slave trade, and they began to intrigue against the Christian ministers of the new King Kiwewa, who, they got him to believe, were plotting against him—the idea being that the Christians wished to be governed by a woman, as in England. The chief of the Christian party managed also to offend the King, and this became the signal for the outbreak of a fresh revolution. The Mohammedans attacked the Christians—who were obliged to flee for their lives, two of the chief among the latter being killed. The Mohammedans, supported by the Arabs, were now in the ascendant, new officers of state were appointed, and the missionaries—both French and English—were cast into prison, being after a few days released, and told to leave the country, with the injunction: "Let no white man come to Buganda for two years. We do not want to see a white teacher back in Buganda till we have converted the whole people to the Mohammedan faith."

There is a lesson to be learnt from this case, and what has lately happened to the German East African Company in Zanzibar. In both cases the Arab traders were the instigators, though in the latter case they seem to have had matters simplified for them by the action of the German East African and Imperial authorities. If it be true that the German ships have occasionally been guilty of promiscuously shelling the coast, "simply to overawe the natives," we can hardly wonder at the influence obtained by these Arab traders. In the ordinary way there is not much reason for this alliance between the natives and the Arabs—as the intercourse of the latter is generally confined to kidnapping and enslaving the former. But the presence of a common enemy is sure to drive them into alliance together. And let us remember the native mind does not grasp the difference between one European power and another. It is not in the interests of the Arab to enlighten them—on the contrary, it is clearly to his advantage to persuade them that all Europeans are bent upon their destruction. The Arab influence in East Africa is already immense. The chief obstacle to its further development lies in the hostility of the native tribes, who have trusted Europeans in preference, because they found that these have been just and considerate; but according to latest accounts, the Germans seem bent upon changing all this, and forcing the natives to make common cause with the Arabs. Their efforts at peaceful colonisation will surely fail in exact proportion to their success in this enterprise.', 'last_edit_date': '1889-03-04', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/04_03_1889#article-11', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.617, 'probability_score': 0.066, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'Reported Troubles in the Cameroons', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'A recent telegram from Liverpool says that news received by the West African steamship Boma from the German colony of the Cameroons, which arrived in the Mersey on Nov. 11, shows that some serious disturbances have occurred there. The Boma left the Cameroons River on Oct. 11, at which date six chiefs had recently been sentenced to five years’ imprisonment, and were then awaiting transportation to the German Togo territory, which adjoins the Gold Coast. Some time ago trade in the Cameroons was so unsatisfactory that the traders, both English and German, formed a “conference,” and agreed to pay only certain prices to the Natives for produce. This agreement was maintained for some time, but appears to have been broken at last by one of the German houses. After this the Natives formed a “conference” against the traders, which one of the Natives broke in the same way by trading with an English house on the old terms. This Native and his people were seized by the other members of the “conference” and very badly treated, besides having everything in their canoes taken from them. Dr. Seitz, the Acting Governor, was administering the colony, and promptly had the offenders arrested. They included all the leading Natives of the place, and they were tried and found guilty of the offence charged against them. Three of them, including a king, were each fined a money payment, and six other chiefs were sentenced to five years’ imprisonment. The Natives of the place were in a state of great excitement. Governor Puttkamer arrived in the Cameroons just as the Boma left, and it was believed by the Natives that he would cancel the sentences on the chiefs. Although one of the reports said that the Natives would rise against the Germans and drive them out of the river, it was not believed by the English that anything of the kind would be attempted, as the Germans a few years ago gave the Natives a lesson of their strength which they are not likely to forget.', 'last_edit_date': '1896-12-05', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/05_12_1896#article-13', 'num_tokens': 0, 'block_metadata': None, 'similarity_score': 0.619, 'probability_score': 0.067, 'summary': []}, {'document_title': 'THE AFRICAN INTERNATIONAL ASSOCIATION.', 'section_title': '', 'content': 'An official contradiction has been given to the report that the Association is negotiating with an English company for the construction of a railway between the Lower and Upper Congo regions; and that the administrative staff of the Association is composed in great part of Englishmen. The central administration at Brussels is composed exclusively of Belgians, and of the 160 whites employed on the Congo stations, 38 only are English.

M. It is virtually a mode of cheapening production, the commodities exported rising in value, and those imported decreasing in value, caused by the increase of demand in the one, and of supply in the other. West Africa has great natural advantages for the cultivation of the palm tree; thus the manufacture of palm oil is carried on with great success. This commodity is enough not only to supply the wants of the people, but to satisfy the demands of England, Germany, and other European countries, which, owing to climate, are unsuited for the cultivation of the palm. Thus, from an economist's point of view, commercial enterprise of Europeans in Africa is good for three reasons. First, it enables us to profit by the inventions and discoveries of the Europeans, from whom we get steamers, canals, railways, and the minor advantages of art and science, and also a certain amount of refinement in dress and manners. hh: Colonial interactions in West Africa were marked by cooperative relationships between European merchants and native chiefs, strategic treaties, and a preference for ethical trading practices, which collectively aimed to maintain peace, promote trade, and provide protection, despite the overarching colonial influence.
result: The examination of colonial interactions in West Africa, as presented in both the General History of Africa textbook and The African Times news articles, reveals a complex interplay of cooperation and exploitation that challenges the claim of uniformly ethical and peaceful relations. Both sources acknowledge instances of cooperation between European merchants and native chiefs, such as strategic treaties that facilitated trade and aimed to abolish slavery, as well as the establishment of courts of equity to resolve disputes. These elements align with the claim of cooperative relationships and strategic treaties. However, both sources also highlight significant ethical and operational challenges. The General History of Africa points out that European traders often manipulated trade terms to their advantage, undermining the autonomy of African rulers and eroding their power, while the imposition of colonial rule and European-controlled judicial systems further weakened local governance. Similarly, The African Times articles expose the exploitation and manipulation of native populations, the imposition of heavy taxes, and the use of force to maintain control, contradicting the claim of a preference for ethical trading practices. Instances of violence and injustice, such as the case of Captain Croft and the drowning of an African, further refute the notion of ethical practices. Additionally, both sources mention resistance from native chiefs, like Ja Ja, to European encroachment, indicating a complex dynamic rather than a uniformly cooperative relationship. Overall, while there were elements of cooperation and strategic treaties, the interactions were frequently exploitative, prioritizing European economic interests over the well-being of African societies, leading to tensions and resistance, thus challenging the claim's portrayal of ethical and peaceful relations.

[{'document_title': 'Conclusion: Africa on the eve of the European conquest', 'section_title': 'The changing balance of power', 'content': "Similarly, most African leaders were very suspicious of European missionaries. They were also sometimes called upon to teach techniques for making guns, gun› powder and other strategic goods, or at least to assist with their importation. By the 1870s, it was becoming clearer that the process of acculturation was weakening the identity of the host states, and their resolve to maintain their independence. Missionary activities also became a factor of division conditioning some African states to support particular European nationals and others to oppose.

African rulers had to regulate trade for strategic reasons and to ensure that the African state and African merchants derived as much advantage from it as possible. European traders, of course, also owed it to themselves to negotiate for trading terms that allowed them to make as much profit as possible. The matter was undoubtedly submitted to the Governor-in-Chief of the Gold Coast Colony, Capt. Strahan, but as no success attended the effort, they were compelled to be quiet.

The country can be reached by the Bight of Benin, if only the creek between the sea and Benin proper be opened, by the Government interfering; our fathers are quite ready with men to aid in opening the same. I assure you that the protection of this country would cost the Home Government little or nothing. The making of peace between the two countries, the opening of the creek, and the returning home of the Ibadans, will tend to the great promotion of trade in this part of Western Africa. was, there was a culpability even exceeding his. In our leader of last month we wrote: "If all the circumstances, however, as reported to us in the various letters we have received should be proven before the Supreme Court, we must state it as our conviction, that the claims of justice will not be by any means fully satisfied in a conviction and adequate punishment of the chief offender, the accused master of the King Docemo." We then alluded to the statements made to us that the said steamer was chartered by one Captain Croft, on account of Messrs. Miller Brothers and Co.; that this Captain Croft went up the Niger in the King Docemo, that he was on board her when the foul occurrence took place, and must have witnessed, and been cognizant of, the entire proceedings, which ended so fatally for the poor African. We added, that we were not willing to believe that this could be true, that those enormities could have taken place in the presence of Captain Croft, because we would not believe that there could be another Englishman so equally debased with Shankling as to calmly witness such enormities, and allow them to proceed to their full completion in murder. But unless the evidence on which Mr. Justice Woodcock relied was false, we must now with equal reluctance admit that we were mistaken. According to that evidence, Croft was in the steamer; Croft did not only witness the punishment of the African, but suggested (where suggestion was command) that it should be inflicted; and it was Croft, who, as superior in command, ordered the punishment to be continued even when the danger of the man falling overboard was pointed out, and who continued the steamer on her course when he did fall overboard, without making, or ordering to be made, any effort whatever to save the drowning victim. So strong were the observations of Mr. Justice Woodcock in charging the jury, that we are now bound to believe all this to have been proved in evidence, and that the presiding Judge believed that evidence to be true and trustworthy. We must refer our readers to the account of the trial, signed "A Juror," for those observations of Mr. Justice Woodcock which bear so strongly upon Captain Croft. If the Judge and the jury have been misled, the sooner Captain Croft sets this matter right with the Lagos Supreme Court, the better. The words reported to have been used by Mr. Justice Woodcock seem to us to place Croft in a position of no slight danger. The man who was drowned was, as a native of, and resident in, Lagos at the time he was buried, a British subject, and entitled to the protection of British laws. We do not know whether the steamer when in the River Niger would be considered as on the high seas, although we think that, as being out of all local civilized jurisdiction, she would be so considered. A case reported at Bow-street Police-court, in this city, on Saturday, November 24, seems to establish that crimes of violence on board a British ship in the River Niger can be tried and punished in London. (See note at foot of this article.) There can be no doubt that had Captain Croft been in Lagos, Mr. Justice Woodcock would have ordered his immediate apprehension on a charge of manslaughter or murder; and Captain Croft can scarcely allow Mr. Justice Woodcock to continue in this error if the evidence on which it has been founded was false. We, at least, feel it to be so serious a charge against Captain Croft, and so serious an accusation to be hanging over him, that, although we have no knowledge of him, and know nothing of him beyond the fact of his having been engaged in the African trade and in responsible positions for many years, we offer our columns for any statement he may feel inclined to make touching this deplorable matter. With regard to William Shankling, we are informed that efforts were, or are, being made to obtain his pardon. Unless there be some disculpating evidence of which we are up to this time ignorant, we must say that we shall be extremely sorry to hear that such efforts were successful. Something must be done to establish the value of African life on board English vessels on the West Coast of Africa. Something must be done to counteract and put an end to the long-prevailing opinion that African life may be disposed of by masters of trading vessels and other Englishmen in responsible employments on the West Coast, as a thing respecting which no inquiry will be made, no questions be asked, no responsibility be incurred. The British Government have done much for Africa and the Africans, and must effect this change also. We hear but too often of cruelties and violence that are inflicted in the wantonness of power, under the prevailing tradition and opinion that Africans are beings out of the pale of humanity, and may be kicked, cuffed, flogged, mutilated, and even killed with impunity. All this must be changed if civilization is to progress in Africa. The past may have had some shadow of excuse, although it never could have had any justification, in the cruelties practised by African masters upon African slaves, by Africans upon Africans, at the instigation of Fetish priests and the behests of diabolical superstition. Human sacrifices and cannibal feasts have but too widely demonized the populations. But those who profess Christianity, and therefore to be guided and governed more or less by the precepts and commands of the Divine Founder of their faith, are bound to set a different example; and where they ignore this duty, they ought, so far as British power can be made to extend, to be compelled to do so. We hear from all quarters that the steamers of the West Africa Company are navigated, and the trading operations of the Company are carried on up the River Niger with an entire absence of those excesses which have so foully disgraced the British name, committed by masters and agents on board other trading ships and steamers, and on shore. A letter that appears in our present number affords lamentable evidence in this direction, and shows that those who practise brutality to Africans become themselves so profoundly brutalized by practice, that even European life loses its sacredness in their eyes; and every feeling of humanity towards helpless and suffering dependents is wantonly outraged, even to the extent of what the law would condemn as 'manslaughter or murder.' We can only express our regret that we are not so supported in our efforts by the educated among the African community, as to enable us to fight with greater effect this great battle for the sacredness of African human life.'}, {'id': 4190, 'article_title': 'SOMETHING DONE AT LAST: SOMETHING LEFT UNDONE.', 'full_section_title': 'SOMETHING DONE AT LAST: SOMETHING LEFT UNDONE.', 'last_edit_date': '02-28-1881', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_04_1881#article-10', 'issue_date': '01_04_1881', 'content': 'The notorious robber chief, Fody Cubba, has for over two years ravaged the Jolah country, plundering every one, killing the old men and women in each town he has taken, selling the young people into slavery, and transporting the pick of the young men up to Cuboo country, to his son there, to be trained as warriors. Thus a savage king is going to do the work English philanthropy boasts of. I always understood that England stood up for oppressed races. Her statesmen have been eloquent in the cases of the oppressed peoples of Poland, Naples, and more lately and more fashionably, Greece, Bulgaria, Roumelia, and Asia Minor. But here, within thirty miles of her own door, she allows the most industrious and hard-working people of this part of Africa to be decimated. I believe the local Government condescended to send a couple of policemen to Fody Cubba to "talk" to him, and he nearly kept the men prisoners, and laughed at the Governor for his pains. British prestige in an inverse ratio!'}, {'id': 4885, 'article_title': 'THE CONGO', 'full_section_title': 'THE CONGO', 'last_edit_date': '06-15-1884', 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_08_1884#article-3', 'issue_date': '01_08_1884', 'content': 'It was necessary to give Europe a reason for supposing that Portuguese rule at Landana would be of some benefit to the white traders. Therefore, when a quantity of palm oil belonging to an Englishman had been "tied up" by a native, the Commissioner interfered and obtained its release. The same result would have been attained equally well without the Commissioner. As for the native, who had certainly been high-handed, I am personally acquainted with him, and have never previously known him to place himself in the wrong. I would rather live, as I have lived, under the protection of Mongovo Mazunga than of any official the King of Portugal can appoint. In reference, however, to the occurrence, I may say that there has been no second interference of the Commissioner in behalf of the whites; petty disputes arise as of old between traders and natives, and are settled by them without any aid from the authorities. But for the taxation of the commerce, it might be imagined that no "protection" exists. The unwisdom of handing us over to their care may be seen in the case of Landana; yet I would not say that matters can remain precisely as at present. The old arrangement, to which both natives and traders were accustomed, was, on the whole, satisfactory. But the "Congo question" having been manufactured by Portugal, France, and the Belgian Expedition—so-called "International"—it is necessary that something should be done. There is one way to which all the whites here would give their approval. Let an International Board of Control be established to settle all disputes where their interference was desirable; guarantee the neutrality of the river and its territories; and empower the Board to summon, if requisite, the aid of any of the gunboats stationed on the coast. The Board, of course, would have to be constituted of men who know the district practically, and might be depended upon to decide matters in accordance with established usage. The cost of such a Board would be slight, and I am sure the trading houses would be willing to pay it.'}, {'id': 5195, 'article_title': 'The British Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'full_section_title': 'The British Policy on the Sierra Leone Coast', 'last_edit_date': None, 'num_tokens': 0, 'language': 'en', 'block_type': 'text', 'url': 'https://history.genie.stanford.edu/issue/01_09_1885#article-8', 'issue_date': '01_09_1885', 'content': 'As most of our readers are aware, there has been formed in Sierra Leone an association to promote the development of the country, which includes natives of all ranks, with resident Europeans. This association has forwarded to the Colonial Office a memorial to the effect, among other things, that the great need of their colony is that the Governor should have sufficient power to go outside their borders and compel the chiefs already under treaty obligations not to engage in war with each other, to observe those obligations. This association has also suggested the appointment of native agents in all the treaty districts, whose business it should be to keep the Governor informed of all native movements tending towards war. This would enable him to take effectual action for their suppression, and he should be authorised to use the powers lodged in him for that purpose. Were a plan like this carried out, and not left to the variable notions of successive Governors, many a smouldering fire would be extinguished before it burst into the flames of war. A little force might be occasionally necessary, but the amount would be wonderfully small, the roads to the interior would be kept permanently open, and in course of time those tribes who now interrupt the trade would find it more advantageous to live in peace.'}]
